words.def: Abhimanyu (अभिमन्यु): Son of Arjuna and Subhadra who was married to Uttara, daughter of King Virata. He was deceitfully killed by the Kauravas during Kurukshetra.[1]
words.name: Abhimanyu

words.def: Āchārya (आचार्य): Teacher or Guru.
words.name: Āchārya

words.def: Achyuta (अच्युत): A synonym of Sri Vishnu.
words.name: Achyuta

words.def: Adhiratha (अधिरथ): Karna's foster-father.
words.name: Adhiratha

words.def: Adi Shankara (आदि शङ्कर): The first Hindu philosopher who consolidated the principles of the Advaita Vedanta philosophy.
words.name: Adi Shankara

words.def: Aditi (अदिति): A goddess of the sky, consciousness, the past, the future and fertility.
words.name: Aditi

words.def: Advaita Vedanta (अद्वैत वेदान्त): A school of Hindu philosophy often called a monistic or non-dualistic system which refers to the indivisibility of the Self (Atman) from the Whole (Brahman).
words.name: Advaita Vedanta

words.def: Agastya (अगस्त्य): A great sage whose life-story the Pandavas learnt while on pilgrimage to holy places, his wife Lopamudra was equally a great sage in her own right.
words.name: Agastya

words.def: Aghāsur (अघासुर): A dragon sent by Kamsa to destroy Krishna
words.name: Aghāsur

words.def: Āgneyāstra (आग्नेयास्त्र): Āgneyāstra is the fire weapon, incepted by God Agni, master of the flames.
words.name: Āgneyāstra

words.def: Agni (अग्‍नि): The sacred Hindu fire god.[2]
words.name: Agni

words.def: Agnihotra (अग्निहोत्र): A sacrifice to God Agni.
words.name: Agnihotra

words.def: Ahi (अहि): Means ("snake"), Vritra was also known in the Vedas as Ahi cognate with Azhi Dahaka of Zoroastrian mythology and he is said to have had three heads.
words.name: Ahi

words.def: Ahamkara (अहंकार): A Sanskrit term that refers to the ego of one's self, the identification of one's own ego.
words.name: Ahamkara

words.def: Ahimsā (अहिंसा): A religious concept which advocates non-violence and a respect for all life.
words.name: Ahimsā

words.def: Airāvata (ऐरावत): Indra's elephant.
words.name: Airāvata

words.def: Ajasat (अजसत):The Prince who plots with Devadatta to kill Buddha
words.name: Ajasat

words.def: Ajatashatru (अजातशत्रु): Having no enemy, friend of all born things, an epithet of Yudhishthira.
words.name: Ajatashatru

words.def: Akampana (अकम्‍पन): Meaning (Unconquerable) - A rākshasa slain by Hanumaān at seize.
words.name: Akampana

words.def: Akshayapatra (अक्षयपत्र): A wonderful vessel given to Yudhishthira by the Sun god which held a never-failing supply of food.
words.name: Akshayapatra

words.def: Alara (अलर) : A famous sage, sought out by Buddha
words.name: Alara

words.def: Alambasa (अलम्‍बस): A Rakshasa friend of Duryodhana who had joined his forces but Satyaki compelled him to flee from the battlefield.
words.name: Alambasa

words.def: Amarāvati (अमरावती): The city of Indra
words.name: Amarāvati

words.def: Amarkantak (अमरकंटक): Amarkantak is a unique natural heritage area in eastern Madhya Pradesh, India. This is the meeting point of the Vindhyas and the Satpuras, with the Maikal Hills being the fulcrum. This is the place from where the Narmada River, the Sone River and Johila River emerge.
words.name: Amarkantak

words.def: Ambā (अम्‍बा), Ambikā (अम्‍बिका), Ambālikā (अम्‍बालिका): The three daughters of King of Benares, Eldest daughter Ambā was in love with King Shālwa
words.name: AmbāAmbikāAmbālikā

words.def: Amrit (अमृत): Ambrosia, the food of the gods, which makes the partaker immortal.
words.name: Amrit

words.def: Ananta (अनन्‍त): Ananta may be 1.The thousand headed nāga that issued from Balrāma's mouth 2. Author and commentator of Katyayana sutra 3. Ananta was the name of present Shekhawati region of Rajasthan in India.
words.name: Ananta

words.def: Andhaka (अंधक): Andhaka was the demon son of Shiva, and was created from a drop of his sweat. He was born blind. After birth, Andhaka was given to Hiranyaksha to be raised, as he had no sons. Later, Andhaka became the king of Hiranyaksha's kingdom.
words.name: Andhaka

words.def: Anga (अंग): Mlechchha kings, a Kaurava supporter.
words.name: Anga

words.def: Angada (अंगद): One of the monkey host; Son of Valī
words.name: Angada

words.def: Aniruddha (अनिरुद्ध): Son of Pradyumna (a rebirth of Shatrughana who married with Chārumati and Ushā
words.name: Aniruddha

words.def: Anjalikā (अंजलिका): The greatest of Arjuna's arrows with which he slays Karna
words.name: Anjalikā

words.def: Anjanā (अंजना): Mother of Hanumāna
words.name: Anjanā

words.def: Anshumat (अंशुमत): A mighty chariot-fighter
words.name: Anshumat

words.def: Anusuya (अनुसूया): Sati Anusuya was wife of the sage Atri and mother of Dattatreya (दत्तात्रेय) who is considered by some Hindus (in western India) to be an incarnation of the Divine Trinity Brahma, Vishnu and Siva.
words.name: Anusuya

words.def: Apsarās (अपसरा): Heavenly nymphs, The dancing girls of Indra's court
words.name: Apsarās

words.def: Aquila (अक्‍विला): Equivalent, Garuda; the divine eagle
words.name: Aquila

words.def: Araṇi (अरणि): An upper and a lower piece of wood used for producing fire by attrition.
words.name: Araṇi

words.def: Āraṇyaka (आरण्यक): Part of the Hindu Śruti that discuss philosophy, sacrifice and the New Year holiday.
words.name: Āraṇyaka

words.def: Arjuna (अर्जुन): The third of Pāndavas and Krishna's cousin. His doubts on the battle field led to Krishna expounding the Gita.[1]
words.name: Arjuna

words.def: Artha (अर्थ): Wealth, one of the objects of human life, the others being Dharma, (righteous- ness), Kama (satisfaction of desires), Moksha (spiritual salvation).
words.name: Artha

words.def: Arundhati (अरुंधति): Wife of sage Vashishta. She was one of the nine daughters of Kardama Prajapati and his wife Devahuti.
words.name: Arundhati

words.def: Arya: 'Noble or Pious.' Was also used as another name for ancient vedic bharatas tribe, whose main rival tribe were the Dasas.
words.name: Arya

words.def: Asamanja (असमंज): Son of Sāgra
words.name: Asamanja

words.def: Ashtavakra (अष्‍टवक्र): A towering scholar while still in his teens.
words.name: Ashtavakra

words.def: Ashta Lakshmi: Eight aspects of goddess Lakshmi, symbolising eight sources of wealth
words.name: Ashta Lakshmi

words.def: Ashvatthāman (अश्‍वत्‍थामां): Son of Dronacharya and last supreme commander of the Kaurava force, strong as a horse
words.name: Ashvatthāman

words.def: Ashvins (अश्‍विन): The divine twins
words.name: Ashvins

words.def: Ashwamedha (अश्‍वमेध): The horse sacrifice
words.name: Ashwamedha

words.def: Asvamedha Yajna (अश्‍वमेध यज्ञ): A horse sacrifice.
words.name: Asvamedha Yajna

words.def: Ashwapati (अश्‍वपति): Uncle of Bharata and Shatrughna
words.name: Ashwapati

words.def: Ashwasena (अश्‍वसेन): Son of Naga Takshaka, who was saved by Indra, while Khandavavana was put into flame by Pandavas. Five mighty arrows shot by Karna
words.name: Ashwasena

words.def: Asita (असित): A sage who held that gambling was ruinous and should be avoided by all wise people.
words.name: Asita

words.def: Asmaka (अस्मक): A Kaurava warrior who attacked Abhimanyu.
words.name: Asmaka

words.def: Astra (अस्त्र): A missile charged with power by a holy incantation.
words.name: Astra

words.def: Asuras: mythological lord beings in Indian texts who compete for power.
words.name: Asuras

words.def: Ātma (आत्‍मा): The underlying metaphysical self, sometimes translated as spirit or soul.
words.name: Ātma

words.def: Ayodhyā (अयोध्या): Unconquuerable, The city in the country of Koshala
words.name: Ayodhyā

words.def: Binod:The Father of intillegent son Birat
words.name: Binod

words.def: Birat:The intillegent son of Binod Timsina and Ganga Timsina
words.name: Birat

words.def: Babhruvahana: Babhruvahana was son of Arjuna by his wife Chitrāngadā.
words.name: Babhruvahana

words.def: Badarikasram (बद्रीकाश्रम): Badarikasram is a place sacred to Vishnu, near the Ganges in the Himalayas, particularly in Vishnu's dual form of Nara-Narayana.
words.name: Badarikasram

words.def: Bahlika (बाह्लिक), Dasharna (दशर्ण): States the kings of which were Kalinga, Magadha, friendly to the Pandavas, Matsya, Panchala, Salva.
words.name: BahlikaDasharna

words.def: Bahu (बाहु): A king of the Solar race. who was vanquished and driven out of his country by the tribes of Haihayas and TaIajanghas. He was father of Sagara.
words.name: Bahu

words.def: Bahuka (बाहुक): The changed name of Nala, as a charioteer of Rituparna, the king of Ayodhya. Also other name of king Bahu.
words.name: Bahuka

words.def: Baladeva (बलदेव): Balarama, elder brother of Sri Krishna.
words.name: Baladeva

words.def: Balarāma (बलराम): Elder brother of Lord Krishna and manifestation of Sheshanaga.[1]
words.name: Balarāma

words.def: Bali: a demon king defeated by the god Vishnu.
words.name: Bali

words.def: Bakāsura (बकासुर): A voracious, cruel and terribly strong Rakshasa or demon who lived in a cave near the city of Ekachakrapura whom Bhima killed to the great relief of the citizens.
words.name: Bakāsura

words.def: Baṇāsura (बाणासुर): Banasura was a thousand-armed asura and son of Bali. He was a powerful and terrible asura. All people even the king of earth and Devas of heaven were afraid of him. Banasura was a follower of Siva. He had a beautiful daughter named Usha.
words.name: Baṇāsura

words.def: Behula (बेहुला):The daughter of Saha, a merchant of Nichhani Nagar; weds Lakshmindara, mentioned in the story of Manasa Devi who was the daughter of Shiva.
words.name: Behula

words.def: Bhadra (भद्र): A mighty elephant
words.name: Bhadra

words.def: Bhadrakālī (भद्रकाली): Bhadrakālī is also known as the gentle Kali, who came into being by Devi's wrath, when Daksha insulted Shiva. She is the consort of Virabhadra.
words.name: Bhadrakālī

words.def: Bhagadatta (भगदत्‍त): King of Pragjyotisha, a Kaurava ally.
words.name: Bhagadatta

words.def: Bhagawān (भगवान): Form of address to Gods and great rishis, example-Bhagawan Sri Krishna, Narada, Vyasa. A Sanskrit word meaning "Holy or Blessed one". It is a title of veneration, often translated as "Lord" and refers to God.
words.name: Bhagawān

words.def: Bhagavad Gītā (भगवद् गीता ): The national gospel contained in Mahābhārata, Part of the epic poem Mahabharata, located in the Bhishma–Parva chapters 23–40. A core sacred text of Hinduism and philosophy.
words.name: Bhagavad Gītā

words.def: Bhagavatī (भगवती): Alias Pārvatī, Shiva's wife
words.name: Bhagavatī

words.def: Bhagīratha (भगीरथ): Son of Dilipa, king of Kosala who worshipped Shiva and brought down Ganges.
words.name: Bhagīratha

words.def: Bhajan (भजन): A Hindu devotional song. Great importance is attributed to the singing of bhajans within the Bhakti movement.
words.name: Bhajan

words.def: Bhaktī (भक्ति): A Sanskrit term that means intense devotion expressed by action (service). A person who practices bhakti is called bhakta.
words.name: Bhaktī

words.def: Bhaktī Yoga (भक्ति योग): The Hindu term for the spiritual practice of fostering of loving devotion to God, called bhakti.[2]
words.name: Bhaktī Yoga

words.def: Bharadwāja (भरद्वाज): A rishi, father of Yavakrida.
words.name: Bharadwāja

words.def: Bharata (भरत): Means "to be or being maintained"). Bharat may be 1. a name of Agni 2. a name of Rudra 3. one of the Adityas 4. Emperor Bharata, son of Dushyanta and Shakuntalā 5. Bharata (Ramayana), a son of Dasharatha, younger brother of Rama 6. Bharata Muni, the author of the Natyashastra 7. Bharata (Bhagavata), the eldest of a hundred sons of a saintly king by name Rishabha Deva according to the Bhagavata purana.
words.name: Bharata

words.def: Bhārata (भारत): Meaning ("descended from Bharata"). Bhārata may refer to 1. The Bhāratas, an Aryan tribe of the Rigveda 2. an early epic forming the core of the Mahabharata (allegedly comprising about a quarter of the extended epic) 3. the Republic of India (properly, Bhārata GaNarājya, भारत गणराज्य).
words.name: Bhārata

words.def: Bhārgava (भार्वग): Karna's divine weapon
words.name: Bhārgava

words.def: Bhaumāsur (भौमासुर): A demon slain by Krishna
words.name: Bhaumāsur

words.def: Bhīma (भीम): The second of Pāndavas who excelled in physical prowess as he was born of the wind-god.
words.name: Bhīma

words.def: Bhīshma (भीष्‍म): Bhīshma was son of Shāntanu, the great Knight and guardian of the imperial house of Kurus.
words.name: Bhīshma

words.def: Bhīshmak (भीष्‍मक): Raja of Kundalpur and father of Rukminī.
words.name: Bhīshmak

words.def: Bhoja s (भोज): A branch of the Yadava clan belonging to Krishna's tribe.
words.name: Bhoja

words.def: Bhumanyu : Nameo of Son of Bharatha. He became emperor of India after Bharat.
words.name: Bhumanyu

words.def: Bhuminjaya (भुमिंजय): Another name of prince Uttara son of Virata who had proceeded to fight the Kaurava armies, with Brihannala as his charioteer.
words.name: Bhuminjaya

words.def: Bhuriśravas (भुरिश्र्वस): Bhurisravas was a prince of the Balhikas and an ally of the Kauravas, who was killed in the great battle of the Mahabharata.
words.name: Bhuriśravas

words.def: Bhūta: A ghost, imp, goblin. Malignant spirits which haunt cemeteries, lurk in trees, animate dead bodies, and delude and devour human beings.
words.name: Bhūta

words.def: Bibhatsu (बिभत्‍सु): One of Arjuna's name meaning a hater of unworthy acts.
words.name: Bibhatsu

words.def: Brahmā (ब्रह्‍मा): Creator of the universe, The Hindu creator god, and one of the Trimurti, the others being Vishnu and Shiva. He must not be confused with the Supreme Cosmic Spirit of Hindu philosophy Brahman.
words.name: Brahmā

words.def: Brahmāstra (ब्रह्‍मास्‍त्र): A divine weapon, irresistible, one given by Lord Brahma himself.
words.name: Brahmāstra

words.def: Brahmachārin (ब्रह्‍मचारिन): A religious student, unmarried, who lives with his spiritual guide, devoted to study and service.
words.name: Brahmachārin

words.def: Brahmacharya (ब्रह्‍मचर्य): Celibacy, chastity; the stage of life of Vedic study in which chastity and service are essential, The word Brahmacharya symbolises a person who is leading a life in quest of Brahma, or in other words a Hindu student
words.name: Brahmacharya

words.def: Brahmadatta (ब्रह्‍मदत्‍त): King of Benares
words.name: Brahmadatta

words.def: Brahman (ब्राह्‍मण): The signifying name given to the concept of the unchanging, infinite, immanent and transcendent reality that is the Divine Ground of all being.
words.name: Brahman

words.def: Brahmin (ब्राह्ममन): One of four fundamental colours in Hindu caste (Varna) consisting of scholars, priests and spiritual teachers.
words.name: Brahmin

words.def: Braj (ब्रज): Braj (also known as Brij or Brajbhoomi) is a region in Uttar Pradesh of India, around Mathura-Vrindavan. It is considered to be the land of Krishna and is derived from the Sanskrit word vraja.
words.name: Braj

words.def: Brihadaswa (बृहदास्‍व): A great sage who visited the Pandavas during their forest hermitage and reminded them of King Nala of Nishadha who also lost his kingdom in the game of dice and who deserted his wife Damayanti because of a curse but ultimately regained both.[3]
words.name: Brihadaswa

words.def: Brihadratha (बृहद्रथ): Commander of three regiments reigned over Magadha and attained celebrity as a great hero, married the twin daughters of the Raja of Kasi. His two wives ate each half of a mango given by sage Kausika and begot half a child each. A Rakshasi recovered the two portions from a dustbin wherein they were thrown and when they accidentally came together, they became a chubby baby, which she presented to the king, saying it was his child, which later became known as Jarasandha.
words.name: Brihadratha

words.def: Brihadyumna (बृहद्युम्‍न): A King, a disciple of sage Raibhya.
words.name: Brihadyumna

words.def: Brihannala (बृहन्नल): Name assumed by Arjuna while living at Virata's court in incognito. He taught arts to Uttarā, the princess of the kingdom of Virata.
words.name: Brihannala

words.def: Brihaspati (बृहस्‍पति): Father of Kacha and priest of devas
words.name: Brihaspati

words.def: Brihatbala (बृहत्बल): A daring warrior who charged at Abhimanyu caught in the Kaurava army's net.
words.name: Brihatbala

words.def: Brindavan (बृन्दावन): A town on the site of an ancient forest which is the region where Lord Krishna spent his childhood days. It lies in the Braj region.
words.name: Brindavan

words.def: Caste (कास्‍ट): Portuguese word to describe in a western context the Hindu system of classification of peoples (jāti)
words.name: Caste

words.def: Chakra (चक्र): An energy node in the human body. The seven main chakras are described as being aligned in an ascending column from the base of the spine to the top of the head. Each chakra is associated with a certain colour, multiple specific functions, an aspect of consciousness, a classical element, and other distinguishing characteristics.
words.name: Chakra

words.def: Chala (चल): A Kaurava warrior.
words.name: Chala

words.def: Champā (चम्‍पा): A city on banks of the Ganges river where Karna found as a babe by Adhiratha and Rādhā
words.name: Champā

words.def: Chāndāla (चांडाल): A person of a degraded caste, whose conduct was much below standard and whose cause pollution.
words.name: Chāndāla

words.def: Chandraketu (चंद्रकेतु): A devotee of Manasā
words.name: Chandraketu

words.def: Channa (चन्न) : A royal servant and head charioteer of Prince Siddhartha, who was to become the Buddha.
words.name: Channa

words.def: Chānd Sadāgar (चांद सदगर): A merchant-prince of Champaka Nagar. Manasā Devi woos the devotion of him
words.name: Chānd Sadāgar

words.def: Charachitra (चरचित्र): A son of King Dhritarashtra who perished in the war.
words.name: Charachitra

words.def: Caraka Saṃhitā (चरक संहिता): An ancient Indian Ayurvedic text on internal medicine written by Caraka. It is believed to be the oldest of the three ancient treatises of Ayurveda.
words.name: Caraka Saṃhitā

words.def: Chavadi: Place of public assembly of the village. It is the property of the entire community. In it all public business is transacted, and it serves also as the village club the headquarters of the village police and guest house for travellers.
words.name: Chavadi

words.def: Chedi (चेदि): A kingdodom of Shishupāla, old name of present Chanderi
words.name: Chedi

words.def: Chekitana (चेकितान): Chekitana was son of Dhrishtaketu, Raja of the Kekayas, and an ally of the Pandavas.
words.name: Chekitana

words.def: Chitra (चित्र): A son of Dhritarashtra killed in the war.
words.name: Chitra

words.def: Chitraksha (चित्राक्ष): One of the many sons of King Dhritarashtra who fell in the war
words.name: Chitraksha

words.def: Chitrakūta (चित्रकूट): Chitrakūta was in mountain forests where Rama, Sita and Lakshmana spent eleven and half years of their exile; The hermitages of Vālmīki, Atri, Sati Anusuya, Dattatreya, Maharshi Markandeya, Sarbhanga, Sutikshna were here; and here the principal trinity of the Hindu pantheon, Brahma, Vishnu and Mahesh, took their incarnations.
words.name: Chitrakūta

words.def: Chitralekha (चित्रलेखा): Chitralekha was a friend of Usha and daughter of minister of Banasura. She was a talented lady who helped Usha to identify the young man, Aniruddha, seen in the dream of Usha. Chitralekha through supernatural powers abducted Aniruddha from the palace of Krishna and brought him to Usha.
words.name: Chitralekha

words.def: Chitrasena (चित्रसेन): King of the Gandharvas who prevented the Kauravas from putting up their camp near the pond where he himself had encamped.
words.name: Chitrasena

words.def: Chitrayudha (चित्रयुद्‍ध): A Kaurava prince who laid down his life in the war.
words.name: Chitrayudha

words.def: Chitravarma (चित्रवर्मा): A brother of Duryodhana who was killed in the war
words.name: Chitravarma

words.def: Chitrangada (चित्रांगद): Elder son of Santanu born of Matsyagandhi (Satyavati) who succeeded his father on the throne of Hastinapura.
words.name: Chitrangada

words.def: Chitrāngadā: Chitrāngadā was one of Arjuna's wives. Arjuna travelled the length and breadth of India during his term of exile. In ancient Manipur in the eastern Himalayas he met Chitrāngadā, the daughter of the king of Manipur and married her. Babhruvahana was soon born to the couple. Babruvahana would succeed his grandfather as king of Manipur.
words.name: Chitrāngadā

words.def: Chyavana (च्‍यवन): A great rishi, husband of beautiful wife Sukanyā whom Ashvins beheld at her bath
words.name: Chyavana

words.def: Dāruka (दारुक): Sri Krishna's charioteer.
words.name: Dāruka

words.def: Dadhichi: Dadhichi was a Vedic king, son of Atharvan, who turned a great Rishi. Dadhicha gave his bones to destroy Vritra, a brahmin, who became the head of the Asuras.
words.name: Dadhichi

words.def: Daityas (दैत्‍य): Daityas were the children of Diti and the sage Kashyapa. They were a race of giants who fought against the gods.
words.name: Daityas

words.def: Daksha (दक्ष): The skilled one, is an ancient creator god, one of the Prajapatis, the Rishis and the Adityas, and a son of Brahma.
words.name: Daksha

words.def: Dākshāyani (दाक्षायणी): Dākshāyani is the Goddess of marital felicity and longevity; she is worshipped particularly by ladies to seek the long life of their husbands. An aspect of Devi, Dākshāyani is the consort of Shiva. Other names for Dākshāyani include Gaurī, Umā, Satī, Aparnā, Lalithā, Sivakāmini.
words.name: Dākshāyani

words.def: Damayantī (दमयंती): She is the wife of Nala whose story is told in the Mahabharata.
words.name: Damayantī

words.def: Dandaka (दंडक): A kingdom and a forest, had the same name, was a colonial state of Lanka under the reign of Ravana. Ravana's governor Khara ruled this province. It was the stronghold of all the Rakshasa tribes living in the Dandaka Forest.
words.name: Dandaka

words.def: Dasharatha (दशरथ): King of Ayodhya and Rama's father.
words.name: Dasharatha

words.def: Dashaarna (दशार्ण): A country whose king attacked Bhagadatta's elephant in an effort to save Bhima.
words.name: Dashaarna

words.def: Dasharna (दशार्ण): Dasharna was an ancient Indian kingdom in Malwa region near Mandsaur. The queen of Chedi kingdom and mother of Damayanti were daughters of king of Dasharna.
words.name: Dasharna

words.def: Demons: A supernatural being that has generally been described as a malevolent spirit. A demon is frequently depicted as a force that may be conjured and insecurely controlled, they were constantly at war with devas.
words.name: Demons

words.def: Devadatta (देवदत्‍त): Name of Arjuna's conch, also Buddha's cousin.
words.name: Devadatta

words.def: Deva (देव): The Sanskrit word for god or deity. It can be interpreted as a demi-god, deity or any supernatural being of high excellence.
words.name: Deva

words.def: Devarata (देवर‍त): Father of Yajnavalkya, the gods had given him a great bow and neither gods, nor gandharvas, nor asuras, nor rākshsa, nor men had might to string that.
words.name: Devarata

words.def: Devakī (देवकी): Mother of Lord Krishna.
words.name: Devakī

words.def: Devala (देवल): A sage who condemned the game of dice as an evil form of gambling and declared it unfit as entertainment for good people, as it usually offered scope for deceit and dishonesty.
words.name: Devala

words.def: Devavrata (देवव्रत): The eighth child of Santanu and Ganga who in time mastered the art yielding arms and learned the Vedas and Vedanta as also the sciences known to Sukra was crowned Yuvaraja (heir apparent), but later vowed to celibacy and was known as Bhishma.
words.name: Devavrata

words.def: Devayanī (देवयानी): The beautiful daughter of Shukracharaya, preceptor of the demons, who fell in love with Kacha, son of Brihaspati, preceptor of the Devas.
words.name: Devayanī

words.def: Devendra (देवेन्‍द्र): King of the Gods.
words.name: Devendra

words.def: Devī (देवी): The female version of a Deva, i.e. a female deity or goddess. Devi is considered to be the Supreme Goddess in Shaktism.
words.name: Devī

words.def: Dhanvantari (धन्‍वंतरी): An avatar of the Hindu God Vishnu. Dhanvantari appears in the Vedas as the physician of the gods, and is the god of Ayurvedic medicine.
words.name: Dhanvantari

words.def: Dharma (धर्म): Righteous course of conduct. Can mean law, rule or duty. Beings that live in harmony with Dharma proceed quicker towards moksha.
words.name: Dharma

words.def: Dharmagranthi (धर्मग्रंथी): Assumed named of Nakula at Virata's court.
words.name: Dharmagranthi

words.def: Dharmananda (धर्मनन्‍द): The delighted of Dharma, a name of Yudhishthira, the son of Dharma or Yama.
words.name: Dharmananda

words.def: Dharmavyadha (धर्मव्‍याध): He possessed the secret of good life and lived in the city of Mithila. He was a meat-seller.
words.name: Dharmavyadha

words.def: Dhananjaya (धनन्‍जय): One of the names of Arjuna.
words.name: Dhananjaya

words.def: Dhanusaksha (धनुसक्ष): A great sage whom Medhavi, son of sage Baladhi, once insulted. He took the form of a bull and butted at that mountain and broke it to pieces. Then Medhavi fell down dead.
words.name: Dhanusaksha

words.def: Dhaumya (धौम्‍य): Preceptor of the Pandavas, who accompanied them during their exile to the Kurujangala forest, singing Sama hymns addressed to Yama, Lord of Death.
words.name: Dhaumya

words.def: Dhrishtadyumna (धृष्‍टद्‍युम्‍न): Supreme commander of the Pandava forces and twin brother of Draupadi.
words.name: Dhrishtadyumna

words.def: Dhrishtaketu (धृष्‍टकेतु): Dhrishtaketu may be 1. A son of Dhrishtadyumna. 2. A son of Sisupala, king of Chedi, and an ally of the Pandavas. 3. A king of the Kekayas, also an ally of the Pandavas. 4. Son of Satyadhriti. 5. Son of Nriga.
words.name: Dhrishtaketu

words.def: Dhritarāshtra (धृतराष्‍ट्र): Elder son of Vichitravirya and Ambika, born blind, father of Duryodhana.
words.name: Dhritarāshtra

words.def: Dharmaputra (धर्मपुत्र): The son of Yama, epithet of Yudhishthira.
words.name: Dharmaputra

words.def: Dhartarashtras (धार्तराष्‍ट्र): Sons of Dhritarashtra
words.name: Dhartarashtras

words.def: Dhruva (ध्रुव): Dhruva was the prince blessed to eternal existence and glory as the Pole Star (Dhruva Nakshatra in Sanskrit) by Lord Vishnu. The story of Dhruva's life is often told to children as an example for perseverance, devotion, steadfastness and fearlessness.
words.name: Dhruva

words.def: Dhumrāksha (धुमराक्ष): The Grey-eye rākshasha appointed by Rāvana who was slain by Hanumāna.
words.name: Dhumrāksha

words.def: Dilipa (दिलीप): Son of Anshumat and father of Bhāgīratha.
words.name: Dilipa

words.def: Dīpāvali (दीपावली, दिवाली): Lit. a row of lamps. A significant 5-day festival in Hinduism occurring between mid October and mid November. It is also popularly known as the Festival of Lights.
words.name: Dīpāvali

words.def: Draupadī (द्रौपदी): Daughter of King Drupada, King of Panchala,who was born from fire. She was the sister of Dhrishyadyumna. She married all the five Pandavas though Arjuna had won her in the Swayamvara, because of the vow that they would share everything in common.
words.name: Draupadī

words.def: Droṇa (द्रोण): A Brāhman discovered by Bhīshma, Son of a Brahmana named Bharadwāja; married a sister of Kripa and a son Aswathama was born to them; learnt military art from Parasurama, the maser. Later he became the instructor to the Kaurava and Pandava princes in the use of arms. He was slain by Dhrishtadyumna in Mahabharata war.
words.name: Droṇa

words.def: Drupada (द्रुपद): King of Panchala, Drona's friend, father of Draupadi who became the wife of the Pandavas
words.name: Drupada

words.def: Duhsāsana (दुःशासन): brother of Duryodhana who dragged Draupadi into the assembly hall and attempted to strip her naked after she had been lost as a wager by Yudhishthira. He eventually gave up when Krishna came to Draupadi's aid. The pandava Bhima killed him at Kurukshetra and drank his blood in accordance with the vow he had taken.[1]
words.name: Duhsāsana

words.def: Durdhara (दुर्धर): A son of Dhritarashtra killed by Bhima in the war.
words.name: Durdhara

words.def: Durgā (दुर्गा): A form of Devi, the supreme goddess. She is depicted as a woman riding a lion with multiple hands carrying weapons and assuming mudras.
words.name: Durgā

words.def: Durjaya (दुर्जय): A brother of Duryodhana who was sent to attack Bhima, to save Karna's life but lost his own.
words.name: Durjaya

words.def: Durmarsha (दुर्मर्श): A son of Dhritarashtra killed by Bhima.
words.name: Durmarsha

words.def: Durmata (दुर्मत): A son of Dhritarashtra who was killed by Bhima.
words.name: Durmata

words.def: Durmukha (दुर्मुख): A chariot-borne warrior on the Kaurava side.
words.name: Durmukha

words.def: Durvāsa (दुर्वास): An ancient sage known for his anger who visited the Kauravas. Duryodhana asked him to visit his cousins, the Pandavas, hoping that they would incur his wrath.[1]
words.name: Durvāsa

words.def: Durvishaha (दुर्विषह): A warrior fighting on the Kaurava side.
words.name: Durvishaha

words.def: Duryodhana (दुर्योधन): The eldest son of the blind king Dhritarashtra by Queen Gandhari, the eldest of the one hundred Kaurava brothers, and the chief antagonist of the Pandavas.
words.name: Duryodhana

words.def: Dushkarma (दुष्‍कर्म): A warrior belonging to the Kaurava side.
words.name: Dushkarma

words.def: Dushyanta (दुष्‍यंत): A valiant king of the Lunar, race, and descended from Puru. He was husband of Sakuntala, by whom he had a son, Bharata. The loves of Dushyanta and Sakuntala, her separation from him, and her restoration through the discovery of his token-ring in the belly of a fish, form the plot of Kalidasa's celebrated play Sakuntala.
words.name: Dushyanta

words.def: Dussaha (दुस्‍सह): A son of Dhritarashtra killed by Bhima.
words.name: Dussaha

words.def: Dvaita (द्वैत): A branch of Hindu philosophy, founded by Shri Madhvacharyathat advocates dualism and stresses a strict distinction between God and souls.
words.name: Dvaita

words.def: Dvaitavana (द्वैतवन): Dvaita Forest or Dvaitavana was situated to the south of the Kamyaka Forest. It contained within it a lake called the Dwaita lake. It was on the south-western outskirts of Kurujangala, near the borders of the desert (northern extension of the Thar desert into Haryana) (3,176). It also lay on the banks of the Saraswati River (known there as the Bhogavati) (3-24,176).
words.name: Dvaitavana

words.def: Dwaitayana (द्वैतायन): A forest where the Kaurava, cows were being bred and housed.
words.name: Dwaitayana

words.def: Dwārakā (द्वारका): Krishna renounced war in Mathura for the greater good and founded and settled in Dwārakā. Leaving the Vrishnis people in Dwaraka, Krishna returned to Mathura and killed Kamsa (his maternal uncle) and Kālayavans demon and made Ugrasen (his maternal grandfather) the king of Mathura.
words.name: Dwārakā

words.def: Dyumatsena (द्‍युमतसेन): King of Shālwas and father of Satyavān.
words.name: Dyumatsena

words.def: Ekachakra (एकचक्र): It was a city where the Pandavas are said to have lived here with their mother, Kunti, when they were exiled to the forest and escaped from the burning of house of lac.
words.name: Ekachakra

words.def: Ekalavya (एकलव्‍य): He was a young prince of the Nishadha tribes, who achieves a skill level parallel to the great Arjuna, despite Drona's rejection of him. He was a member of low caste and he wished to study in the gurukulam of Dronacharya.
words.name: Ekalavya

words.def: Fire-God: Same as Agni.
words.name: Fire-God

words.def: Flute: Lord Krishna had a flute (called a Bansuri in Indian languages) which he used to play in the woods and all the herd-girls of Braj used to go out on the voice of this flute.
words.name: Flute

words.def: Gajasura (गजासुर): Gajasura (elephant demon) is the name used to refer to demon Nila when he took the form of an elephant and attacked Shiva. He was destroyed by Ganapati.
words.name: Gajasura

words.def: Gaṇapati (गणपति): Lord of the territory, The fulfiller of desire, the god of merchants, Second son of Shiva and Pārvati. Amanuensis of Vyasa who agreed to write down without pause or hesitation the story of the Mahabharata dictated by Vyasa.
words.name: Gaṇapati

words.def: Ganges (गंगा): A holy river in Northern India, believed to be a goddess by Hindus (see Ganges in Hinduism), Equivalent Ganges, The story of the birth of the Ganges was told to Rama and Laxmana by Vishvamitra.
words.name: Ganges

words.def: Gaṇesha (गणेश): The god of good fortune, commonly identified for his elephant head.
words.name: Gaṇesha

words.def: Gaṇeśa Chaturṭhī (गणेश चतुर्थी): Ganesh Chaturthi is an occasion or a day on which Lord Ganesha, the son of Shiva and Parvati, makes his presence on earth for all his devotees. It is the birthday of Lord Ganesha. The festival is observed in the Hindu calendar month of Bhaadrapada, starting on the shukla chaturthi.
words.name: Gaṇeśa Chaturṭhī

words.def: Gāndhārī (गांधारी): Dhritarashtra's wife and queen mother of the Kauravas.
words.name: Gāndhārī

words.def: Gandharva s (गंधर्व): A class of celestial beings regarded as specialists in music.
words.name: Gandharva

words.def: Gāṇdīva (गाण्डीव): Arjuna's most potent bow.
words.name: Gāṇdīva

words.def: Gangadwara (गंगद्वार): A place where sage Agastya and his wife performed penance.
words.name: Gangadwara

words.def: Garuda (गरुड): It is a large mythical bird or bird-like creature that appears in both Hindu and Buddhist mythology.
words.name: Garuda

words.def: Gaurī (गौरी): Gaurī or Dākshāyani is the Goddess of marital felicity and longevity; she is worshipped particularly by ladies to seek the long life of their husbands. An aspect of Devi, Dākshāyani is the consort of Shiva.
words.name: Gaurī

words.def: Gāyatrī (गायत्री): A revered mantra in Hinduism, found in the Yajur Veda.
words.name: Gāyatrī

words.def: Ghatotkacha (घटोत्‍कच): Son of Bhima from demoness Hidimba.
words.name: Ghatotkacha

words.def: Girivraja (गिरिव्रज): A Wealthy city in Kekaya Kingdom also called Rajagriha.
words.name: Girivraja

words.def: Gītā (गीता): See Bhagwad Gita
words.name: Gītā

words.def: Gopa s (गोप): Equivalent, herd-boys
words.name: Gopa

words.def: Gopāla (गोपाल): Name of Krishna indicating his origin as a god of flocks and herds.
words.name: Gopāla

words.def: Gopīs (गोपी): Gopi is a word of Sanskrit origin meaning 'cow-herd girls'.
words.name: Gopīs

words.def: Govardhan (गोवर्धन): Govardhan is a hill located near the town of Vrindavan in India.
words.name: Govardhan

words.def: Govinda (गोविन्‍द): One of the epithets of Sri Krishna and Vishnu; it means a cow-keeper and refers to Krishna's occupation in Gokula, the colony of cowherds
words.name: Govinda

words.def: Grihastha (गृहस्‍थ): The second of the four phases(Purushartha) of a man, when a person gets married and settles down in life and begets children.
words.name: Grihastha

words.def: Guha (गुह): King of Nishādha
words.name: Guha

words.def: Guru (गुरु): Revered preceptor, A spiritual teacher. In contemporary India, the title and term "Guru" is widely used within the general meaning of "wise man".
words.name: Guru

words.def: Guru Pūrṇimā (गुरु पूर्णिमा): The day of full moon, Purnima, in the month of Ashadh of the Hindu calendar is traditionally celebrated by Hindus as Guru Pūrṇimā. On this day, devotees offer puja (worship) to their Guru.
words.name: Guru Pūrṇimā

words.def: Hamsa (हंस), Hidimbā (हिडिम्‍बा), Kamsa (कंस): Allies of King Jarasandha; the last married the two daughters of Jarasandha. Also Krishna's step-uncle whom Krishna killed.
words.name: Hamsa

words.def: Halayudha (हलयुद्ध): Plough-weaponed, an epithet of Balarama who wielded a plough as his weapon.
words.name: Halayudha

words.def: Hanumāna (हनुमान): Wise and learned monkey devotee of Sri Rama, who possessed extraordinary powers of discrimination and wisdom and who searched and found Sita in her confinement in Lanka. Son of Vayu and Anjana.
words.name: Hanumāna

words.def: Hari (हरि): Hari is another name of Vishnu or God in Vaishnavism, Smarta or Advaitan Hinduism, and appears as the 650th name in the Vishnu sahasranama.
words.name: Hari

words.def: Harivamsa (हरिवंश): Harivamsa is an important work of Sanskrit literature. It is a kind of appendix to the Mahābhārata, that runs to 16,375 verses and focuses specifically on the life of Lord Krishna.
words.name: Harivamsa

words.def: Hastināpura (हस्‍तिनापुर): Hastinapura is the capital and the kingdom of the Kauravas, the descendants of Kuru, which include the Pandavas. The throne of this city is the prize over which the great war of the epic is fought.
words.name: Hastināpura

words.def: Hidimbā (हिडिम्‍बा): A powerful Asura, who had yellow eyes and a horrible aspect. He was a cannibal, and dwelt in the forest to which the Pandavas retired after the burning of their house. He had a sister named Hidimbi, whom he sent to lure the Pandavas to him; but on meeting with Bhima, she fell in love with him. By his mother's desire Bhima married her, and by her had a son named Ghatotkacha.
words.name: Hidimbā

words.def: Hindu scripture: Sacred texts of Hinduism mostly written in Sanskrit. Hindu scripture is divided into two categories: Śruti – that which is heard (i.e. revelation) and Smriti – that which is remembered (i.e. tradition, not revelation).
words.name: Hindu scripture

words.def: Hinduism: A worldwide religious tradition that is based on the Vedas and is the direct descendent of the Vedic religion. It encompasses many religious traditions that widely vary in practice, as well as many diverse sects and philosophies.
words.name: Hinduism

words.def: Hiranyakashipu (हिरण्‍यकश्यप): Hiranyakashipu was an Asura, and also a King of Dravida whose younger brother, Hiranyaksha was killed by Varaha, one of the avatars of Vishnu. Identical with Shishupāla and Rāvana.
words.name: Hiranyakashipu

words.def: Hiranyaksha (हिरण्‍याक्ष): Hiranyaksha was an Asura of the Daitya race, and a King of Dravida who was killed by Lord Vishnu after he took the Earth to the bottom of the ocean. He had an older brother named Hiranyakashipu.
words.name: Hiranyaksha

words.def: Holikā (होलिका): Holika was a demoness who was killed on the day of Holi. She was the sister of King Hiranyakashipu. The story of Holika's conflict signifies the triumph of good over evil.
words.name: Holikā

words.def: Hrishikesha (हृषीकेश): Krishna.
words.name: Hrishikesha

words.def: Ikshvaku (इक्ष्वाकु): The word Ikshvaku means "bitter gourd". Ikshvaku was the first king and founder of the Sun Dynasty in Vedic civilization in ancient India. He was the son of Manu (the first man on earth), sired by the Sun God, Surya. Rama, of the epic Ramayana is a descendant of the house of Ikshvaku. So are Bhagiratha, Dasharatha, Luv and Kusa.
words.name: Ikshvaku

words.def: Ilvala (ईवल): Ilvala and Vatapi were asuras, the rulers of Badami, formerly known as Vatapi, was named after asura king Vatapi.
words.name: Ilvala

words.def: Indra (इन्‍द्र): King of the Gods. The chief deity of the Rigveda, the god of weather and war as well as Lord of Svargaloka in Hinduism.
words.name: Indra

words.def: Indrajīt (इन्‍द्र जीत): Son of Ravana, King of Lanka, also known as Meghanath, who conquered Indra, the Lord of Gods and received his name 'Indra-jit' (Victor of Indra), and who was killed by Rama's brother Lakshmana.
words.name: Indrajīt

words.def: Indraprastha (इन्‍द्रप्रस्‍थ): Indraprastha (City of Indra) was a major northern city in ancient India that was the capital of the kingdom led by the Pandavas in the Mahabharata epic, located upon the banks of the river Yamuna, believed to be the site of present Purana Qila, in the modern national capital of Delhi.
words.name: Indraprastha

words.def: Indrasena (इन्‍द्रसेन): A kinsman of the Pandavas, son of Nala and Damayanti.
words.name: Indrasena

words.def: Indrasenā (इन्‍द्रसेना): Daughter of Nala and Damayanti.
words.name: Indrasenā

words.def: Indrakila (इन्‍द्रकिला): A mountain Arjuna passed on his way to the Himalayas to practise austerities to acquire powerful new weapons from Lord Mahadeva.
words.name: Indrakila

words.def: Iravan (इरवन): Arjuna's son by a Naga princess Ulupi who fell in the battle on the eighth day, fought on the side of the Pandavas, killed by the Rakshasa Alumvusha.
words.name: Iravan

words.def: Ishvara (ईश्व‍र): A Hindu philosophical concept of God referring to the Supreme Being which is the lord and the ruler of everything. Hinduism uses the term Ishvara exclusively to refer to the Supreme God in a monotheistic sense.
words.name: Ishvara

words.def: Jāmbavān (जाम्‍बवान): Jambavan or Jamvanta is a bear in Hinduism and believe to lived from Treta Yuga to kaliYuga.
words.name: Jāmbavān

words.def: Jambudvīpa (जम्बुद्वीप): The name of the dvipa ("continent") of the terrestrial world, as envisioned in the cosmologies of Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism, which is the realm where ordinary human beings live. Its name is said to derive from a Jambu tree.
words.name: Jambudvīpa

words.def: Jambumali (जम्बुमली):The warrior Ravana sends to slay Hanuman when Hanuman not satisfied with finding Sita dashed about the Ashoka grove and broke the trees and spoiled the pavilions.
words.name: Jambumali

words.def: Janaka (जनक): King of Mithila, a great Rajarishi; father of Sita, wife of Rama.
words.name: Janaka

words.def: Janamejaya (जनमेजय): A king who conducted a great sacrifice for the well being of the human race.
words.name: Janamejaya

words.def: Janārdana (जनार्दन): A name of Krishna
words.name: Janārdana

words.def: Jarāsandha (जरासंध): A rākshasa father-in-law of Kamsa, Son of Brihadratha. Mighty king of Magadha of whose prowess all Kshatriyas were afraid. Killed by Bhima in a thirteen-day non-stop physical combat: with Sri Krishna and Arjuna as witnesses.
words.name: Jarāsandha

words.def: Jarita (जरित), Laputa (लपुत): Female companions of a saranga bird, who was a rishi named Mandapala in his previous birth when he was refused admission to heaven because he was childless.
words.name: JaritaLaputa

words.def: Jalāsura (जलासुर): A demon killed by Bhima.
words.name: Jalāsura

words.def: Japa (जप): A spiritual discipline in which a devotee repeats a mantra or the name of God. The repetition can be aloud, just the movement of lips or in the mind.
words.name: Japa

words.def: Jātaka (जातक): The Jataka is a voluminous body of folklore and mythic literature, primarily associated with the Theravada Buddhist tradition, as written in the Pali language (from about the 3rd century, C.E.); The story of Rama is told in one of Jātakas.
words.name: Jātaka

words.def: Jatāsura (जटासुर): A Rakshasa who disguised himself as a Brahman and carried Yudhishthira, Sahadeva, Nakula, and Draupadi. He was overtaken and killed by Bhima.
words.name: Jatāsura

words.def: Jatāyū (जटायू): Jatāyū was king of all the eagles-tribes, the son of Aruna and nephew of Garuda. A demi-god who has the form of an (eagle), he tries to rescue Sita from Ravana, when Ravana is on his way to Lanka after kidnapping Sita. His brother was Sampatī
words.name: Jatāyū

words.def: Jaya (जय): A son of King Dhritarashtra, who was killed by Bhima in the war
words.name: Jaya

words.def: Jayadratha (जयद्रथ): A warrior on the side of Kauravas who closed the breach effected by Abhimanyu in the Chakravyuha military formation by Dronacharya and trapped him inside.
words.name: Jayadratha

words.def: Jayatsena (जयत्‍सेन): A kinsman of the Pandavas.
words.name: Jayatsena

words.def: Jīwal (जीवल): The charioteer of Rituparna, king of Ayodhya, who accompanied with Bahuka.
words.name: Jīwal

words.def: Jnana (ज्ञान): Knowledge of the eternal and real
words.name: Jnana

words.def: Kacha (कच): Grandson of sage Angiras and son of Brihaspati, who went to seek knowledge under Sukracharya as a brahmacharin. Devayani, the preceptor's lovely daughter, fell in love with him. The Asuras (demons) suspecting him of wanting to steal the secret of reviving the dead, killed him a number of times. But due to Devayani's love for him, her father brought him back to life every time he was killed. Ultimately the secret was learnt by the devas who then succeeded in defeating the asuras.
words.name: Kacha

words.def: Kagola (कगोल): A disciple of the great sage and teacher of Vedanta, Uddalaka. Although virtuous and energetic, he lacked the intelligence needed to master the Vedas. He was also the father of Ashtavakra, whose legendary crookedness was a result of his twisting in the womb whenever Kagola made a mistake in reciting the Vedas.[1]
words.name: Kagola

words.def: Kaikeyī (कैकेयी): She was the youngest of King Dasharatha's three wives and a queen of Ayodhya. She was the mother of Bharata.
words.name: Kaikeyī

words.def: Kailāsh (कैलास): It is a peak in the Gangdisê mountains, the source of rivers in Asia—the Indus River, the Sutlej River, and the Brahmaputra River—and is considered as a sacred place in four religions—Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism and Bön faith. The mountain lies near Lake Manasarowar and Lake Rakshastal in Tibet.
words.name: Kailāsh

words.def: Kaitabh (कैतभ): Kaitabh is an asura associated with Hindu religious cosmology. He along with his companion, Madhu, originated from one of the ears of God Vishnu. Kaitabh and Madhu were designed to annihilate Brahma.
words.name: Kaitabh

words.def: Kālayāvan (कालयावन): Kālayāvan was an asura who surrounded Mathura with an army of thirty million monstrous friends. Then Krishna departed to build a city of Dwārkā amidst sea, transported all his people to this city and left them in Dwārkā. Then Krishna returned and slew Kālayāvan.
words.name: Kālayāvan

words.def: Kāl-Purush (काल-पुरुष): The time-man, Bengali name of Orion.
words.name: Kāl-Purush

words.def: Kali (कलि): Kali was a demon, the personified spirit of the Fourth yuga who possesses Nala.
words.name: Kali

words.def: Kalī Yuga (कली युग): Kalī Yuga (lit. Age of Kali, also known as The Age of Darkness), is one of the four stages of development that the world goes through as part of the cycle of Yugas, as described in Hindu scriptures, the others being Dwapara Yuga, Treta Yuga, and Satya Yuga.
words.name: Kalī Yuga

words.def: Kālī (काली): A dark, black aspect of the mother-goddess Devi whose consort is Shiva.
words.name: Kālī

words.def: Kālindī (कालिन्‍दी): Kālindī was daughter of the Surya (Sun) who marries Lord Krishna while he was ruling at Dwarka, Kālindī is also another name for the river Yamuna in northern India.
words.name: Kālindī

words.def: Kāliyā (कालिया): Kāliyā was the name of a poisonous hydra or Nāga living on the bank of Yamuna River. Kāliyā was quelled by Krishna and sent to his abode in Ramanaka Dwīpa.
words.name: Kāliyā

words.def: Kāl nāginī (काल नागिनी): A serpent who kills Lakshmindara, the son of Chand Sadagar who was a merchant-prince of Champaka Nagar.
words.name: Kāl nāginī

words.def: Kalki (कल्कि): The tenth Avatar of Vishnu who is yet to come and will appear as a man on a horse at the end of Kali Yug.
words.name: Kalki

words.def: Kāma (काम): Best understood as aesthetics, the definition of Kama involves sensual gratification, sexual fulfillment, pleasure of the senses, love, and the ordinary enjoyments of life regarded as one of the four ends of man (purusharthas).
words.name: Kāma

words.def: Kāmadeva (कामदेव): Kāmadeva is the Hindu god of love. He is represented as a young and handsome winged man who wields a bow and arrows.
words.name: Kāmadeva

words.def: Kamboja s (कम्बोज): Enemies of the Kauravas whom Karna had defeated
words.name: Kamboja

words.def: Kāmadhenu (कामधेनु): Kamadhenu was a divine cow believed to be the mother of all cows. Like her child Nandini, she could grant any wish for the true seeker. Kamadhenu provided Vasishta with his needs for the sacrifices. Kamadhenu (kama-dhenu, 'wish-cow'), was a miraculous cow of plenty who could give her owner whatever he desired.
words.name: Kāmadhenu

words.def: Kampilya (कम्पिल्‍य): Capital of the Panchala Kingdom ruled by Drupada.
words.name: Kampilya

words.def: Kamsa (कंस): Maternal Uncle of Sri Krishna and son of Ugrasena, also son-in-law of Jarasandha, whom Sri Krishna killed.
words.name: Kamsa

words.def: Kamyaka Forest (काम्यक वन): Kamyaka forest is mentioned in Mahabharata being situated at the head of the Thar desert, near the lake Trinavindu was situated on the western boundary of the Kuru Kingdom, on the banks of the Saraswati River. It lay to the west of the Kurukshetra plain.
words.name: Kamyaka Forest

words.def: Kanika (कणिक): Minister of Sakuni.
words.name: Kanika

words.def: Kanka (कंक): Assumed name of Yudhishthira at Virata's court.
words.name: Kanka

words.def: Kaṇva (कण्‍व): Father of Shakuntala.
words.name: Kaṇva

words.def: Kanyā pūjā (कन्या पूजा):A Hindu custom to worship virgin girls as a symbol of the pure basic creative force.
words.name: Kanyā pūjā

words.def: Kapila (कपिल ऋषि): A Vedic sage credited as one of the founders of the Samkhya school of philosophy. He is prominent in the Bhagavata Purana, which features a theistic version of his Samkhya philosophy.
words.name: Kapila

words.def: Karkotaka (कर्कोटक): The naga who bit Nala at the request of Indra, transforming Nala into a twisted and ugly shape.
words.name: Karkotaka

words.def: Kartavirya Arjuna (कार्तवीर्य अर्जुन): Kārtavīrya Arjuna was King of Mahishamati, kshatriya of Ramayana period believed to have a thousand arms. He had beheaded Jamadagni, father of Parashurama. In revenge, Parashurama killed the entire clan of Kartavirya Arjuna. Ravana was comprehensively defeated and was put to humiliation by him.
words.name: Kartavirya Arjuna

words.def: Karma (कर्म): A Sanskrit term that comprises the entire cycle of cause and effect.
words.name: Karma

words.def: Karma Yoga (कर्म योग): The practise of disciplining action. Karma yoga focuses on the adherence to duty (dharma) while remaining detached from the reward. It states that one can attain Moksha (salvation) by doing his duties in an unselfish manner.[2]
words.name: Karma Yoga

words.def: Karṇa (कर्ण): A matchless warrior, son of the Sun god and Kunti. Disciple of Parasurama. Also son of Radha, his foster-mother, and was known as Radheya.
words.name: Karṇa

words.def: Kārtavīrya (कार्तवीर्य): A great warrior who defeated Ravana, King of Lanka.
words.name: Kārtavīrya

words.def: Kārtikeya (कार्तिकेय): Commander of the armies of the devas, A god born out of a magical spark created by Shiva, his father. His brother is Ganesha.
words.name: Kārtikeya

words.def: Kashyapa (कश्‍यप): An ancient sage, father of the Devas, Asuras, Nagas and all of humanity. He is married to Aditi, with whom he is the father of Agni and the Savitrs. His second wife, Diti, begot the Daityas. Diti and Aditi were daughters of King Daksha and sisters to Sati, Shiva's consort. One of Dashratha's counsellors also.
words.name: Kashyapa

words.def: Kauravas (कौरव): Kaurava is a Sanskrit term, that means a descendant of Kuru, alternate name of sons of Dhritarashtra.
words.name: Kauravas

words.def: Kausalyā (कौसल्‍या): She was the eldest of King Dasharatha's three wives and a queen of Ayodhya. She was the mother of Rama.
words.name: Kausalyā

words.def: Kausikam (कौसिकम्): A sage who learnt from Dharmavyadha the secret of Dharma, of performing one's duty.
words.name: Kausikam

words.def: Kaustubha (कौस्तुभ:): is a divine jewel - the most valuable stone "Mani", which is in the possession of lord Vishnu.
words.name: Kaustubha

words.def: Kekaya (केक‍य): A brave warrior on the Pandava side into whose chariot Bhima got during the fighting on the sixth day. Usinaras, the Sibi, the Madras, and the Kekayas were the direct descendants of Yayati's son Anu.
words.name: Kekaya

words.def: Kesava (केसव): One of the names of Sri Krishna.
words.name: Kesava

words.def: Keshinī (केशिनी): Wife of Sāgara
words.name: Keshinī

words.def: Ketama (केतम): Another chief whose head was cut off by Drona.
words.name: Ketama

words.def: Ketu (केतु): Ketu is generally referred to as a "shadow" planet. It has a tremendous impact on human lives and also the whole creation. Astronomically, Ketu and Rahu denote the points of intersection of the paths of the Sun and the Moon as they move on the celestial sphere.
words.name: Ketu

words.def: Khaṇdavaprastha (खाण्डवप्रस्‍थ): The ancient capital from where the ancestors of Pandavas, Nahusha and Yayati ruled. The Pandavas rebuilt the ruined city and erected palaces and forts and renamed it Indraprastha.
words.name: Khaṇdavaprastha

words.def: Khandava Vana (खांडववन):Khandava Vana was an ancient forest mentioned in the epic Mahabharata, inhabited by Naga tribes. It lay to the west of Yamuna river, in modern-day Delhi territory. Pandavas cleared this forest to construct their capital city called Indraprastha.
words.name: Khandava Vana

words.def: Khara (खर): Khara was younger brother of Rāvana who was slain by Rama.
words.name: Khara

words.def: Kichak a (किचक): Sudeshna's brother, commander-in-chief of Virata's army, who made advances to Sairandhri (Draupadi). He was invited to meet her at night at the ladies dancing hall and was met instead by Valala (Bhima) dressed up as a female who killed him (Kichaka).
words.name: Kichak

words.def: Khir (खिर): The grand son of Krishana.
words.name: Khir

words.def: Kinnars (किन्‍नर): Human birds with instruments of music under their wings.
words.name: Kinnars

words.def: Kirāta (किरात): Huntsman, The non-Aryan aborigines of the land. They are mentioned along with Cinas for Chinese. Kiratas are believed to be of Tibeto-Burman origin.
words.name: Kirāta

words.def: Kirmira (किर्मीर): Kirmira was a Rakshasa, the brother of Bakasura, who lived in the Kamyaka Forest, and used to terrorize the Rishis who inhabited that forest. He ran into the Pandavas when they began their exile in the Kamyaka forest. Upon learning that Bheema was present, who had slain his brother Bakasura, the Rakshasa then challenged the Pandava to fight. After a fierce battle, Bhishma choked Kirmira to death.
words.name: Kirmira

words.def: Kishkindhā (किष्किन्‍धा): Kishkindhā was the kingdom ruled by a Vanara King Sugreeva, the younger brother of Bali, during the Ramayana period. This was the kingdom where he ruled with the assistance of his most intelligent minister, Hanuman.
words.name: Kishkindhā

words.def: Kosala (कोशल): Kosala was an ancient Indian Aryan kingdom, corresponding roughly in area with the region of Oudh. Its capital was Ayodhya, where Rama was born.
words.name: Kosala

words.def: Kripa (कृपा): The concept of Divine Grace in Hinduism, especially in Bhakti Yoga.
words.name: Kripa

words.def: Kripāchārya (कृपाचार्य): Aswathama's uncle who advocated a combined assault on Arjuna in battle as against Karna's boast that he could take him on single-handed.
words.name: Kripāchārya

words.def: Krishṇa (कृष्‍ण): The eighth avatar of Vishnu, one of the most worshipped by many Hindus. Krishna is famous for his lecture to Arjuna written in the Bhagavad Gita.
words.name: Krishṇa

words.def: Krishna-Dwaipāyana (कृष्‍ण द्वैपायन): Another name of Sage Vyasa.
words.name: Krishna-Dwaipāyana

words.def: Krishna Janmashtami (कृष्ण जन्माष्टमी): A Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Lord Krishna, an avatar of Hindu deity Vishnu.
words.name: Krishna Janmashtami

words.def: Krauncha (क्रौंच): Curlew-heron.
words.name: Krauncha

words.def: Krauncha-Vyuha (क्रौंच व्‍युह): military formation on a pattern supposed to resemble a heron with outstretched beak and spreading wings. In ancient Indian practice, armies were arrayed for battle in formations of definite patterns, each of which had a name such as Chakra, or Kurma or Krauncha, or Makara according to a real or fancied resemblance.
words.name: Krauncha-Vyuha

words.def: Kritavarma (कृतवर्म): A notable Yadava warrior fighting on the side of Kaurava forces.
words.name: Kritavarma

words.def: Kshatriya (क्षत्रिय): One of the four fundamental colours (Varnas) in Hindu tradition, consisting of the warriors, soldiers and rulers of society.
words.name: Kshatriya

words.def: Kshatradharma (क्षात्रधर्म): This is a form of spiritual practice that involves "Protection of the seekers and destruction of the evildoers". In other words, it is the duty of fighting against evil as told by lord Krishna to Arjuna in the Bhagavad Gita.
words.name: Kshatradharma

words.def: Kubera (कुबेर): One of the gods of wealth and riches.
words.name: Kubera

words.def: Kuchasthala (कुचस्‍थल): A city where Krishna stayed the night on his way to the court of Dhritarashtra.
words.name: Kuchasthala

words.def: Kumāra (कुमार): Son of Shiva and Parvati who conquered and slew the demon Taraka.
words.name: Kumāra

words.def: Kumbha (कुम्भ): Kumbha was a rakshasa who led a host against the monkeys when Hanumana fetches healing herb.
words.name: Kumbha

words.def: Kumbhakarna (कुम्भकर्ण): Brother of Ravana, King of Lanka, who was asleep most of the time because of the curse of Brahma.
words.name: Kumbhakarna

words.def: Kundalpur (कुण्‍डलपुर): Capital of Raja Bhismak who was father of Rukmini, the wife of Krishna.
words.name: Kundalpur

words.def: Kundinapura (कुण्‍डिनपुर): Capital of Vidarbha.
words.name: Kundinapura

words.def: Kuntī (कुंती): Mother of Pandavas, Daughter of Sura also known as Pritha. She was given in adoption to the king's childless cousin Kuntibhoja and was named Kunti after her adoptive father.
words.name: Kuntī

words.def: Kunti-Madri (कुंती-माद्री): Queens of King Pandu who gave birth to three and two sons known as the Pandavas in the forest where he spent many years for having committed some sin. The sons were known as Yudhishthira, Bhima, Arjuna, Nakula, and Sahadeva.
words.name: Kunti-Madri

words.def: Kurma (कुर्म): Tortoise, The second Avatar of Vishnu where he took the form of a tortoise.
words.name: Kurma

words.def: Kurujangala (कुरुजाङ्गल): An ancient kingdom of India, in the north near the Yamuna and Ganges rivers. The main cities of the region are Hastinapura and Indraprastha. Its kings are sometimes called the Kurus. On a modern map of India, this kingdom roughly forms most of the Haryana state. Indraprastha (now known as Delhi the capital of India) was its capital.
words.name: Kurujangala

words.def: Kurukshetra (कुरुक्षेत्र): Plain of, scene of great battle between the Pandavas and Kurus for the throne of Hastinapura resulted in a battle in which a number of ancient kingdoms participated as allies of the rival clans. The location of the battle was Kurukshetra in the modern state of Haryana in India.
words.name: Kurukshetra

words.def: Kurus (कुरु): The name of an Indo-Aryan tribe and their kingdom in the Vedic civilization of India. Their kingdom was located in the area of modern Haryana. Bhisma was their guardian.
words.name: Kurus

words.def: Kusha (कुश): Kusha and his twin brother Lava are the children of the Hindu God Rama and his wifeSita, whose story is told in the Ramayana
words.name: Kusha

words.def: Kusasthala (कुसस्थल): one of the provinces asked by Pandavas,
words.name: Kusasthala

words.def: Lakshagrah (लाक्षागृह): The house of lac, The palace made out of lac at Benares where Pandavas along with Kunti were kept with a sense of banishment.The house was made with flammable materials which Purochana was to ignite at the opportune moment with the Pandavas entrapped inside. However, Vidura had seen through Duryodhana's plan and sent a miner to tunnel a shaft which the Pandavas used to escape.[1]
words.name: Lakshagrah

words.def: Lakshmaṇa (लक्ष्मण): Younger stepbrother of Rama and son of Sumitra and King Dasharatha. Duryodhana's gallant young son also bore this name.
words.name: Lakshmaṇa

words.def: Lakshmī (लक्ष्मी): Goddess of prosperity, wealth and good fortune. She is the consort of Vishnu and an aspect of Devi.
words.name: Lakshmī

words.def: Lakshmīndara (लक्ष्मीन्‍दर): Son of Chand Sadagar who weds Behula. He was slain by Kal-nagini but restored to life by Mansa.
words.name: Lakshmīndara

words.def: Lankā (लंका): An island city, generally identified with Ceylon, the home of Ravana.
words.name: Lankā

words.def: Lava (लव): Kusa and Lava were sons of Rama and Sita.
words.name: Lava

words.def: Lomasa (लोमस): A brahmana sage who advised the Pandavas to reduce their retinue while repairing to the forest. Those unable to bear the hardships of exile were free to go to the court of Dhritarashtra or Drupada, king of Panchala. He accompanied Yudhishthira on his wanderings.
words.name: Lomasa

words.def: Lopamudra (लोपमुद्रा): Daughter of the king of Vidarbha who married the sage Agastya.
words.name: Lopamudra

words.def: Lord Narayana (नारायण): Refuge of men; Mahavishnu.
words.name: Lord Narayana

words.def: Mādhava (माधव): One of the names of Krishna. It means the Lord of Lakshmi.
words.name: Mādhava

words.def: Madhu (मधु): The name of Kingdom of Shtrughna.
words.name: Madhu

words.def: Madhusudana (मधुसुदन): Another name of Krishna, the slayer of the asura Madhu.
words.name: Madhusudana

words.def: Mahābhārata (महाभारत): One of the two major ancient Sanskrit epics of India, the other being the Ramayana. The Mahabharata is of religious and philosophical importance in India; in particular, the Bhagavad Gita, which is one of its chapters (Bhishmaparva) and a sacred text of Hinduism.
words.name: Mahābhārata

words.def: Mahādeva (महादेव): Another name of Shiva.
words.name: Mahādeva

words.def: Mahāpārshwa (महापार्शव): One of Ravana's generals.
words.name: Mahāpārshwa

words.def: Mahārāksha (महाराक्ष): Son of Khara slain at Lanka.
words.name: Mahārāksha

words.def: Mahāvishnu (महाविष्‍णु): Lord of the Universe who took human birth in order to wrest his kingdom from Emperor Bali for the salvation of the world. Lord Vishnu also took birth as Rama, son of Dasharatha, to kill Ravana, King of Lanka.
words.name: Mahāvishnu

words.def: Mahendra (महेन्‍द्र): A King who had attained heaven. Also the name of a mountain upon which Hanumana rushes while searchin Sita, shaking it in wrath and frightening every beast that lived in its woods and caves.
words.name: Mahendra

words.def: Mainaka (मैनक): Another mountain, well wooded and full of fruits and roots, Hanumana coursed through the air while searchin Sita.
words.name: Mainaka

words.def: Maitreya (मैत्रेय): A sage who visited the court of Dhritarashtra, expressed sorrow at the Pandava's plight, advised Duryodhana not to injure the Pandavas for his own good.
words.name: Maitreya

words.def: Makandi : One of the provinces asked by Pandavas, A province running along the banks of the Ganges, to the south of Hastinapura. Kampilya the capital city of Panchala was situated in the Makandi province within the southern Panchala kingdom (1,140).
words.name: Makandi

words.def: Makara Sankaranti (मकर संक्रान्ति): A huge Religious festival regarding Sun. Lit. Makara means Capricorn and Sankranti is transition. It is about transition of Sun into Capricorn on its celestial path.
words.name: Makara Sankaranti

words.def: Mālinī (मालिनी): Malini was the name of river that was flowing in the forest where the ashrama of Kanva rishi was situated and Dushyanta fell in love with Shakuntala.
words.name: Mālinī

words.def: Manasā Devī (मन्‍सादेवी): Manasa Devi the goddess of snakes; the daughter of Shiva by a beautiful mortal woman. She was no favourite of her step mother, Bhagavati, or Parvati, Shiva's wife.
words.name: Manasā Devī

words.def: Manasaputra (मानसपुत्र): Literally "sons of mind". Wise men, created from the brain of Brahma. They are listed as Atri, Bharadwaja, Gotama, Jamadagni, Kashyapa, Vashishtha and Vishwamitra. Some sources add more names to this list.
words.name: Manasaputra

words.def: Mānasarovar (मानसरोवर): A sacred lake in the Himalayas
words.name: Mānasarovar

words.def: Mandara (मंदर): The mountain used as a churning stick in Samudra manthan for churning the ocean using Vasuki nāga as rope by gods on one side and asuras on other side.
words.name: Mandara

words.def: Mandavya (मंदव्‍य): A sage wrongly punished by the king by being impaled as the chief of robbers who had clandestinely hidden their stolen goods in a corner of his hermitage when he was in deep contemplation. Lord Dharma gave him this punishment for having tortured birds and bees in his childhood. At this Mandavya cursed Dharma who was born as Vidura, the wise, to the servant maid of Ambalika, wife of King Vichitravirya, who offered her to Sage Vyasa in place of Ambalika.
words.name: Mandavya

words.def: Mandhatri: Mandhatri was a king, son of Yuvanaswa, of the race of Ikshvaku, and author of a hymn in the Rigveda.
words.name: Mandhatri

words.def: Mandodarī (मंदोदरी): Mandodari was the daughter of the King of Danavas, Mayasura and celestial dancer, Hema. She was the first wife of the Lord of Lanka Ravana.
words.name: Mandodarī

words.def: Manipura: 'City of jewels' in Sanskrit. Manipura is the third primary chakra according to Hindu tradition. It is positioned at the navel region and it has ten petals which match the vrittis of spiritual ignorance, thirst, jealousy, treachery, shame, fear, disgust, delusion, foolishness and sadness.
words.name: Manipura

words.def: Mantharā (मंथरा): Mantharā was a servant who convinced Kaikeyi that the throne of Ayodhya belonged to her son Bharata and that Rama should be exiled from the kingdom.
words.name: Mantharā

words.def: Mantra (मंत्र): An incantation with words of power. A religious syllable or poem, typically from the Sanskrit language. They are primarily used as spiritual conduits, words and vibrations that instill one-pointed concentration in the devotee. Other purposes have included religious ceremonies to accumulate wealth, avoid danger, or eliminate enemies. Mantras are performed through chanting.
words.name: Mantra

words.def: Manu Smriti (मनुस्मृति): The Manusmriti translated Laws of Manu is regarded as an important work of Hindu law and ancient Indian society. Manu was the forefather of all humans and author of Manu Smriti. Certain historians believe it to have been written down around 200 C.E. under the reign of Pushymitra Shunga of Sangha clan.
words.name: Manu Smriti

words.def: Mārīcha (मारीच): A character in the Ramayana, uncle of Ravana who transformed himself into a golden deer at the behest of Ravana to entice Sita.
words.name: Mārīcha

words.def: Mārkandeya (मार्कण्‍डेय): A sage who told Yudhishthira the story of a brahmana, Kausika.
words.name: Mārkandeya

words.def: Marutta (मरुत्त): A king of the Ikshwaku dynasty whose sacrifice was performed by Samvarta in defiance of Indra and Brihaspati.
words.name: Marutta

words.def: Mātalī (मातली): Charioteer of Indra who took Arjuna to the kingdom of gods.
words.name: Mātalī

words.def: Matanga (मतंग): A rishi during Ramayana period, Rama and Laxman pass by while searching Sita on way to mountain Rishyamūk on which dwelt Sugriva.
words.name: Matanga

words.def: Mathurā (मथुरा): The capital of Yadavas which was invaded by Kams
words.name: Mathurā

words.def: Matrikas: A group of mother goddesses.
words.name: Matrikas

words.def: Matsya (मत्‍स्‍य): The first Avatar of Vishnu, where he came in the form of a fish
words.name: Matsya

words.def: Māyā (मा‍या): Maya is the limited, purely physical and mental reality in which our everyday consciousness has become entangled. Maya is believed to be an illusion, a veiling of the true, unitary Self—the Cosmic Spirit also known as Brahman. Maya originated in the Hindu scriptures known as the Upanishads.
words.name: Māyā

words.def: Mayasura (मयासुर): Maya (मय), or Mayasura was a great ancient king of the Asura, Daitya and Rakshasa races upon earth. He was also the chief architect of the peoples of the netherworlds.
words.name: Mayasura

words.def: Medhavi (मेधवी): Son of Sage Baladhi who desired that his son should live as long as a certain mountain lasted. Filled with conceit, Medhavi angered Dhanushaksha who killed him by taking on the form of a bull and butting the mountain until it was broken to pieces.[1]
words.name: Medhavi

words.def: Menakā (मेनका): Menakā is considered one of the most beautiful of the heavenly Apsaras. She was sent by Indra, the king of the Devas, to break the severe penance undertaken by Vishwamitra.
words.name: Menakā

words.def: Meru (मेरु): An ancient mountain and mythical centre of the universe on which was situated the city of Brahma. Becoming jealous of Meru, the Vindya began to grow very high obstructing the sun, the moon and the planets. Agastya whom the Vindhya mountain respected asked it to stop growing until he crossed it on his way to the south and returned to the north again. But he did not return at all, having settled in the south.
words.name: Meru

words.def: Mithilā (मिथिला): Mithilā was a kingdom in ancient India. It existed in the eastern Gangetic plains in areas which is today spread over Uttar Pradesh and Bihar states of India, and parts of Nepal. Raja Janaka, father of Sita, was king of this kingdom.
words.name: Mithilā

words.def: Mitra (मित्र): One of the Adityas.
words.name: Mitra

words.def: Moksha (मोक्ष): Refers to liberation from the cycle of death and rebirth. In higher Hindu philosophy, it is seen as a transcendence of phenomenal being, of any sense of consciousness of time, space, and causation (karma).
words.name: Moksha

words.def: Muchukunda (मुचुकुंद): Muchukunda was a great sage who kills Kalayavan, the great Yavana warrior king in the Indian epic Mahabharata.
words.name: Muchukunda

words.def: Mukāsura (मुकासुर): Mukāsura was a demon, friend of Kauravas, who was sent to disturb the austerities, Arjuna was performing at Mount Kailash. Mukāsura went to forest where Arjuna was practicing his vows of prayer, vigil, and fast and attacked Arjuna in the form of a boar to kill. At the same time Shiva came in the form of a huntsman and saved him. Shiva gave Arjuna the Gandiva, the divine bow, and blessed him.
words.name: Mukāsura

words.def: Nachiketa (नचिकेता): Nachiketa was son of a cowherd of the name Vājashrava, who was offered to Yama to find a place in Heaven by his father. Nachiketatas with his wits learnt the wisdom taught by death, found the Brahman and was freed from death.
words.name: Nachiketa

words.def: Nāga (नाग): Nāga is the Sanskrit and Pāli word for a minor deity taking the form of a very large snake, found in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. The use of the term nāga is often ambiguous, as the word may also refer, in similar contexts, to one of several human tribes known as or nicknamed "Nāgas"; to elephants; and to ordinary snakes, particularly the King Cobra and the Indian Cobra, the latter of which is still called nāg (नाग) in Hindi and other languages of India.
words.name: Nāga

words.def: Nāgas (नाग): Nāgas were a group who spread throughout India during the period of the epic Mahabharata. The demi-god tribe called Suparnas (in which Garuda belonged) were arch-rivals of the Nagas. The well known Nagas are Ananta, Vasuki, Takshaka, Karkotaka and Airavata.
words.name: Nāgas

words.def: Nāga panchami (नाग पंचमी): The festival of Nāga panchami is celebrated in Hindus to pay respect to Nāgas. The five Nāgas worshipped on Nāga panchami are Ananta, Vāsuki, Taxak, Karkotaka and Pingala.
words.name: Nāga panchami

words.def: Nagavanshi (नाग वंशी): Nagavanshi dynasty is one of the Kshatriya dynasties of India. It includes a number of Jats and Rajput clans. The worshippers of Nāga (serpent) were known as Nāgā or Nāgil. The descendants of Nagas were called Nagavanshi.
words.name: Nagavanshi

words.def: Nahusha (नहुष): A mighty king who was made king of the gods because Indra had disappeared due to his killing Vritra through sin and deceit.
words.name: Nahusha

words.def: Naimiṣāraṇya (नैमिषारण्य): Naimiṣāraṇya (Naimisha Forest) was an ancient forest mentioned in the epic Mahabharata. It lay on the banks of the Gomati River (in Uttar Pradesh). The whole narration of Mahabharata took place at Naimisha forests, during a conclave of sages headed by sage Saunaka.
words.name: Naimiṣāraṇya

words.def: Naivedhya (नैवेध्य): Food or eatables prepared as offerings to God, prior to the oblation. (See also: Prasad)
words.name: Naivedhya

words.def: Nakula (नकुल): Fourth brother of the Pandavas.
words.name: Nakula

words.def: Nala (नल): King of Nishadha who lost his kingdom in a game of dice and deserted his wife Damayanti because of a curse.
words.name: Nala

words.def: Nanda (नंद): Nanda is head of a tribe of cowherds referred as Holy Gwals and foster-father of Krishna, who was allegedly given to him by Vasudeva. Nanda was married to Yasoda. Krishna derives his name Nandalal (meaning son of Nanda) from him.
words.name: Nanda

words.def: Nandi (नंदि): Nandi is the white bull which Shiva rides, and the leader of the Ganas. The white color of the bull symbolizes purity and justice.
words.name: Nandi

words.def: Nandinī (नन्‍दिनी): Vasishtha's divinely beautiful cow, child of Kamadhenu.
words.name: Nandinī

words.def: Narasiṃha (नरसिंह): The fourth Avatar of Vishnu. He is a mixed form of a man and a lion.
words.name: Narasiṃha

words.def: Nara (नर): Arjuna or Dhananjaya.
words.name: Nara

words.def: Nārada (नारद): Narada is the Hindu divine sage, who is an enduring chanter of the names Hari and Narayana which other names for Vishnu, considered to be the supreme God by Vaishnavites and many other Hindus. He is regarded the Manasputra of Brahma as he was born of his thoughts. He is regarded as the Triloka sanchaari, the ultimate nomad, who roams the three lokas of Swargaloka, Mrityuloka and Patalloka to find out about the life and welfare of people.
words.name: Nārada

words.def: Nārāyaṇa (नारायण): Nārāyaṇa is an important Sanskrit name for Vishnu. The name is also associated with Brahma and Krishna. He is also identified with, or as the son of, the original man, Purusha.
words.name: Nārāyaṇa

words.def: Nārāyaṇāsrama (नारायणाश्रम): A charming forest where the Pandavas had halted during their wanderings.
words.name: Nārāyaṇāsrama

words.def: Nārāyaṇastra ( नारायणास्त्र ): Narayanastra is the personal missile weapon of Vishnu in his Narayana form, this astra lets loose a powerful tirade of millions of deadly missiles simultaneously.
words.name: Nārāyaṇastra

words.def: Narishyanta (नरिष्यन्त): Narishyanta was son of Vaivasvata Manu and belongs to solar race of Kshatriyas.
words.name: Narishyanta

words.def: Narmadā (नर्मदा): The Nerbudda river, one of the most important sacred rivers, originating from Amarkantak is believed to have descended from the sky by the order of Lord Shiva. The personified river is variously represented as being daughter of a Rishi named Mekala (from whom she is called Mekala and Mekala-kanya), as a daughter of the moon, as a 'mind-born daughter' of the Somapas, and as sister of the Nagas. It was she who brought Purukutsa to the aid of the Nagas against the Gandharvas, and the grateful snake-gods made her name a charm against the venom of snakes.
words.name: Narmadā

words.def: Navadurga (नवदुर्गा): Literally means nine Durgas, constitute, according to Hindu mythology, the manifestation of Durga in nine different forms.
words.name: Navadurga

words.def: Navaratri (नवरात्रि): A Hindu festival of worship and dance. The word Navaratri literally means nine nights in Sanskrit. During these nine nights and ten days, nine forms of Shakti/Devi are worshipped.
words.name: Navaratri

words.def: Netā (नेता): Netā was daughter of Shiva and friend of Manasa Devi.
words.name: Netā

words.def: Nikumbha (निकुम्‍भ): One of Ravana's generals who led the rakshasas against the host of monkeys and was slain.
words.name: Nikumbha

words.def: Nīla (नील): Son of Agni; One of the monkey host placed at the gate guarded by Prahasta.
words.name: Nīla

words.def: Nirvāṇa (निर्वाण): Literally "extinction" and/or "extinguishing", is the culmination of the yogi's pursuit of liberation. Hinduism uses the word nirvana to describe the state of moksha, roughly equivalent to heaven.
words.name: Nirvāṇa

words.def: Nishādha (निषाध): A country where Indra, Lord of the gods had lived once disguised as a brahmana. King of the Nishadha was Guha who guarded Rama after he crossed Koshala kingdom on his exile.
words.name: Nishādha

words.def: Om, or Aum (ॐ): the most sacred syllable in Hinduism, first coming to light in the Vedic Tradition. The syllable is sometimes referred to as the "Udgitha" or "pranava mantra" (primordial mantra); not only because it is considered to be the primal sound, but also because most mantras begin with it.
words.name: OmAumUdgitha

words.def: Pānchajanya (पांचजन्‍य): Name of Krishna's conch.
words.name: Pānchajanya

words.def: Palāsa (पलास): A tree Butea frondosa also called "flame of the forest".
words.name: Palāsa

words.def: Pānchāla (पांचाल): Pānchāla corresponds to the geographical area between the Ganges River and Yamuna River around the city of Kanpur and Benares. Anciently, it was home to an Indian kingdom, the Panchalas, one of the Mahajanapadas.
words.name: Pānchāla

words.def: Pānchālī (पांचाली): Another name of Draupadi, Queen of the Pandavas and daughter of King Drupada.
words.name: Pānchālī

words.def: Pānchālya (पांचाल्य): A son of King Drupada who died in the war.
words.name: Pānchālya

words.def: Panchvatī (पंचवटी): The place beside the river Godavari where Rama, Sita and Laxmana stayed in exile.
words.name: Panchvatī

words.def: Pāṇḍavaḥ (पाण्‍डव): Pandavas in Sanskrit pāṇḍavaḥ are the five acknowledged sons of Pandu, by his two wives Kunti and Madri. They are Yudhishthira, Bhima, Arjuna and Nakula, Sahadeva
words.name: Pāṇḍavaḥ

words.def: Pāṇḍu (पाण्‍डु): Second son of Vichitravirya and Ambalika who succeeded to the throne of Hastinapura on his father's death, as his elder brother Dhritarashtra was born blind, father of the Pandavas.
words.name: Pāṇḍu

words.def: Paramhamsa (परमहंस): The supreme swan
words.name: Paramhamsa

words.def: Pārāsara (पारासर): A great sage, father of Veda Vyasa.
words.name: Pārāsara

words.def: Parashurama (परसुराम): Sixth avatara of Vishnu, the son of Jamadagni. His name literally means Rama-with-the-axe. He received an axe after undertaking a terrible penance to please Shiva, from whom he learned the methods of warfare and other skills. Parashurama's creation was a mistake as his mother was given a concoction made to produce a Kshatriya child. Parashurama was of mixed varna.
words.name: Parashurama

words.def: Pārtha (पार्थ): Another name of Arjuna.
words.name: Pārtha

words.def: Paravasu (परवसु): Son of Raibhva and elder brother of Arvavasu whose wife was violated by Yavakrida, who was killed with a spear by a fiend for his sin.
words.name: Paravasu

words.def: Parikshit (परिक्षित): Son of Abhimanyu and grandson of the Pandavas who was crowned king after the holocaust claimed the Kauravas and the Pandavas.
words.name: Parikshit

words.def: Parṇada (पर्णाद): The name of a brahman who brought news of Nala to Damayanti.
words.name: Parṇada

words.def: Pārvatī (पार्वती): Goddess of love, the consort of Shiva and mother of Ganesha,Rukmini prayed to her for saving her from the cruel Sisupala king of Chedi, as she had set her heart on marrying Krishna.
words.name: Pārvatī

words.def: Pāśupatāstra (पाशुपतास्त्र): Pāśupatāstra is the irresistible and most destructive personal weapon of Siva discharged by the mind, eyes, words or a bow.
words.name: Pāśupatāstra

words.def: Paurava (पौरव): A Kaurava hero.
words.name: Paurava

words.def: Pavanrekhā (पवनरेखा): Wife of Ugrasena, mother of Kams.
words.name: Pavanrekhā

words.def: Phalguna (फल्‍गुन): Arjuna.
words.name: Phalguna

words.def: Pitāmaha (पितामह): Literally grandfather, which however carried no imputation of senile infirmity but denotes the status of the pater familias.
words.name: Pitāmaha

words.def: Prabhasa (प्रभास): The Vasu who seized Vasishtha's divine cow.
words.name: Prabhasa

words.def: Pradyumna (प्रद्‍युम्‍न): Son of Krishna and Rukmani.
words.name: Pradyumna

words.def: Prahasta (प्रहस्‍त): Means long-head, One of Ravana's generals.
words.name: Prahasta
