words.def: Prajāpatī (प्रजाप‍ित): Prajāpatīs are a group (or one) of creation gods, children of Brahma, including Daksha.
words.name: Prajāpatī

words.def: Pramanakoti (प्रमाणकोटि): A beautiful spot on the banks of the Ganges, to the north of Hastinapura, the Kuru capital (1,128). Duryodhana built a palace here for disporting himself in the waters of Ganges. A huge banyan tree was the mark of that place (3,12). Here he poisoned the food of Bhima, bound him and threw him into Ganges. Bhima was rescued by the Naga tribes living in the vicinity (1,128) (8,83) (9,56).
words.name: Pramanakoti

words.def: Prasad (प्रसाद): Food or other offerings, considered to be sanctified, after being presented to God. (See also: Naivedhya)
words.name: Prasad

words.def: Pratikhami (प्रतिखामी): Duryodhana's charioteer.
words.name: Pratikhami

words.def: Prayāg (प्रयाग): The holy place at Allahabad where Ganges and Yamuna meet.
words.name: Prayāg

words.def: Prithā (प्रिथा): Mother of Karna and of the Pandavas; equivalent Kunti.
words.name: Prithā

words.def: Puṇdarikaksha (पुण्डरिक्ष ): Krishna, the lotus-eyed one.
words.name: Puṇdarikaksha

words.def: Purāṇa (पुराण): Purana meaning "ancient" or "old" is the name of a genre (or a group of related genres) of Indian written literature (as distinct from oral literature). Its general themes are history, tradition and religion. It is usually written in the form of stories related by one person to another.
words.name: Purāṇa

words.def: Purochana (पुरोचन ): An architect and friend of Duryodhana, who built a beautiful wax palace named "Sivam" in Varanavata. Kunti prepared a lavish feast which left him intoxicated and led to his death as the wax palace burnt down.[1]
words.name: Purochana

words.def: Purumitra (पुरुमित्र ): A Kaurava warrior
words.name: Purumitra

words.def: Purushārtha (पुरुषार्थ): The four chief aims of human life. Arranged from lowest to highest, these goals are: sensual pleasures (kama), worldly status and security (artha), personal righteousness and social morality (dharma), and liberation from the cycle of reincarnation (moksha).
words.name: Purushārtha

words.def: Purushottama (पुरुषोत्तम): An epithet of Sri Krishna. It is one of the names of Vishnu and means the Supreme Being.
words.name: Purushottama

words.def: Pushkara: The brother of Nala to whom nala lost his kingdom and all that he possessed in gambling.
words.name: Pushkara

words.def: Rādhā (राधा): Rādhā is one of the gopis (cow-herding girls) of the forest of Vrindavan, Krishna plays with her during his upbringing as a young boy; The other Radha is the wife of the charioteer Adhiratha, who found an abandoned new-born boy, whom he named Karna.
words.name: Rādhā

words.def: Rāhu (राहु): Rahu is a snake that swallows the sun or the moon causing eclipses. Rahu is one of the navagrahas.
words.name: Rāhu

words.def: Raibhya (रैभ्य): A sage whose hermitage was situated on the banks of the Ganges, near Rishikesh, a place, which gets its name, from Lord Vishnu appearing to him as Hrishikesh. The Pandavas during their wanderings visited it. This ghat was very holy. Bharata, son of Dasharatha bathed here. Indra was cleansed of his sin of killing Vritra unfairly by bathing in this ghat. Sanatkumar became one with God. Aditi, mother of the gods, prayed here to be blessed with a son.
words.name: Raibhya

words.def: Radheya (राधेय): Son of Radha, a name of Karna, who as a foundling was brought up as a son by Radha, the wife of the Charioteer Adhiratha.
words.name: Radheya

words.def: Rajasūya (राजसूय): A sacrifice performed by a king to be entitled to assume the title of "Emperor".
words.name: Rajasūya

words.def: Rā́kṣasaḥ (रा॑क्षस): A rakshasa alternately, raksasa or rakshas is a demon or unrighteous spirit in Hinduism.
words.name: Rā́kṣasaḥ

words.def: Rāma (राम): The Seventh Avatara of Vishnu. The life and heroic deeds of Rama are written in the Sanskrit epic, The Ramayana.
words.name: Rāma

words.def: Ramanaka dwīpa (रमणक द्वीप): The home of Kaliya Naga, a poisonous hydra, on the banks of Yamuna river.
words.name: Ramanaka dwīpa

words.def: Rāmāyaṇa (रामायण): Part of the Hindu smriti, written by Valmiki. This epic of 24,000 verses in seven kandas (chapters or books) tells of a Raghuvamsa prince, Rama of Ayodhya, whose wife Sita is abducted by the rakshasa Ravana.
words.name: Rāmāyaṇa

words.def: Rāma-navamī (राम नवमी): A Hindu festival, celebrating of the birth of Lord Rama. The day falls on the Navami, ninth day of the Chaitra month of Hindu lunar year in 'Shukla paksha'.
words.name: Rāma-navamī

words.def: Rambhā (रम्‍भा): An apsara in the court of Indra.
words.name: Rambhā

words.def: Ratī (रती): Ratī is the goddess of passion and lust, and a daughter of Daksha. She married Kamadeva, the God of love.
words.name: Ratī

words.def: Rāvaṇa (रावण): King of Lanka who abducted Sita, the beautiful wife of Ramachandra. Ravana is depicted in art with up to ten heads, signifying that he had knowledge spanning all the ten directions.
words.name: Rāvaṇa

words.def: Rewatī (रेवती): Daughter of Raja Rewat of Arntā who marries Balarama
words.name: Rewatī

words.def: Ṝgveda (ऋग्वेद): The Rigveda is a collection of Vedic Sanskrit hymns counted as the holiest of the four religious texts of Hindus, known as the Vedas.
words.name: Ṝgveda

words.def: Rishabha (ऋषभ): Rsabha, the bull, a Hindu god mentioned in epic and Puranic literature, is an unusual avatar of Vishnu. The second note of the Indian gamut (Shadja, rishabha, gandhara, madhyama, panchama, daivata, nishada -sa, ri, ga, ma, pa, dha, ni.)
words.name: Rishabha

words.def: Ṛta (ऋतं): Vedic principle of natural order believed to regulate and coordinate the operation of the universe on the natural, moral and sacrificial levels.
words.name: Ṛta

words.def: Ṛṣi (ऋषि): Rishi, also known as Mantradraṣṭa ("seer of the Mantras") and Vedavaktāra ("chanter of the Vedas") is a seer who "heard" (cf. śruti) the hymns of the Vedas. A rishi is regarded as a combination of a patriarch, a priest, a preceptor, an author of Vedic hymns, a sage, a saint, an ascetic, a prophet and a hermit into a single person.
words.name: Ṛṣi

words.def: Rishyamūk (ऋष्यमूक): Mountain on which Sugriva dwelt.
words.name: Rishyamūk

words.def: Rishyasringa (ऋष्यश्रृंग): Son of sage Vibhandaka, who had grown up seeing no mortal except his father. The king of Anga, which was afflicted with a dire famine, to bring rain and plenty, invited him.
words.name: Rishyasringa

words.def: Rituparṇa (ऋतुपर्ण): The king of Ayodhya to whom Nala became the charioteer.
words.name: Rituparṇa

words.def: Rohiṇi (रोहिणि): The wife of Vasudeva and mother of Balarama
words.name: Rohiṇi

words.def: Romapada (रोमपद): King of Anga which was once visited by a great drought.
words.name: Romapada

words.def: Rudra (रुद्र): A Rigvedic god of the storm, the hunt, death, Nature and the Wind. Rudra is an early form of Shiva and a name of Shiva in the Shiva sahasranama.
words.name: Rudra

words.def: Rudra nritya (रुद्र नृत्‍य): Siva's cosmic dance of destruction.
words.name: Rudra nritya

words.def: Rukma (रुक्‍म): Elder brother of Rukmani, Heir apparent to the throne of Vidarbha. When defeated by Balarama and Krishna he established a new city Bhojakata, ashamed to return to Kundinapura, the capital of Vidarbha, and ruled over it.
words.name: Rukma

words.def: Rukmiṇī (रुक्‍मिणी): Daughter of Raja Bhismak, born at Kundalpur. Rukmini was the first wife and queen of Krishna, the 8th avatar of Vishnu. She was an avatar of Lakshmi.
words.name: Rukmiṇī

words.def: Ruparekha (रूपरेखा): Lit. meaning a treak of Beauty. A statue in the throne of Vikramaditya.
words.name: Ruparekha

words.def: Shachī (शची): Wife of Indra, king of the gods on whom Nahusha's evil eye fell. Through the help of Brihaspati, she caused Nahusha's downfall and restored Indra as the leader of the Devas.[1] She was also known as Indrani.
words.name: Shachī

words.def: Sadhana (साधना): Spiritual exercise by a Sadhu or a Sadhaka to attain moksha, which is liberation from the cycle of birth and death (Samsara), or a particular goal such as blessing from a deity.
words.name: Sadhana

words.def: Sagara (सगर): King Sagar is one of the greatest kings of Suryavansha in the Satya Yuga. He was king of Ayodhya, ancestor to King Dasharatha. He had two wives Keshini and Sumati. Asamanja was his son from Keshini.
words.name: Sagara

words.def: Sahadéva (सहदेव): Youngest of the Pandava princes who offered the first honors to Krishna at the Rajasuya sacrifices.
words.name: Sahadéva

words.def: Saibya (सैब्‍य): A ruler friendly to the Pandavas.
words.name: Saibya

words.def: Sairandhri (सैरंध्री): A maid servant or female attendant employed in royal female apartments.
words.name: Sairandhri

words.def: Saindhava (सैंधव): Jayadratha.
words.name: Saindhava

words.def: Śakra (सक्र): Śakra is identified with the Vedic deity Indra. Śakra is sometimes named as one of the twelve Ādityas.
words.name: Śakra

words.def: Shakuni (शकुनि): Shakuni was the brother of Gandhari. He was very fond of his nephew Duryodhana. He won the Pandavas' half of the kingdom for his nephew, as a wager in a rigged game of dice.
words.name: Shakuni

words.def: Salva (सल्‍व): Friend of Sisupala, who besieged Dwaraka Sri Krishna's kingdom to avenge Sisupala's death at the latter's hand.
words.name: Salva

words.def: Shalya (शल्‍य): Ruler of Madradesa and brother of Madri and uncle of the Pandavas who because of having received hospitality from Duryodhana went over to his side.
words.name: Shalya

words.def: Samādhi (समाधि): A term used in yogic meditation. Samadhi is also the Hindi word for a structure commemorating the dead.
words.name: Samādhi

words.def: Samba : Sambu was son of Krishna, who married Lakshmana, daughter of Duryodhana.
words.name: Samba

words.def: Sāmkhya (सांख्य): A school of philosophy emphasising a dualism between Purusha and Prakrti, propounded by sage Kapila.
words.name: Sāmkhya

words.def: Sampāti (सम्पाति): Sampati was one of the two sons of Aruna, elder brother of Jatayu. Sampati lost his wings when he was a child.
words.name: Sampāti

words.def: Samsaptaka (संसप्‍तक): One who has taken a vow to conquer or die, and never to retreat. The Samsaptakas were suicide-squads, vowed to some desperate deed of daring.
words.name: Samsaptaka

words.def: Samsara (संसार): Means wandering, The tree worlds constitute Samsara. Refers to the concept of reincarnation or rebirth in Indian philosophical traditions.
words.name: Samsara

words.def: Samvarta (संवर्त): Brihaspati's younger brother, a person of great learning.
words.name: Samvarta

words.def: Samba (संब): A Yadava youngster dressed as a woman who gave birth to a mace, as foretold by rishis.
words.name: Samba

words.def: Samudra manthan (समुद्र मन्थन): Samudra manthan or The churning of the ocean of milk is one of the most famous episodes in the Puranas and is celebrated in a major way every twelve years in the festival known as Kumbha Mela.
words.name: Samudra manthan

words.def: Sanga (संग): Son of Virata. When king Virata was wounded, he had to get into Sanga's chariot, having lost his chariot, horses and charioteer
words.name: Sanga

words.def: Sanjaya (संजय): The narrator who tells blind Dhritarashtra the progress of the war from day to day. He told the king that a victim of adverse fate would first become perverted and loses his sense of right and wrong. Time would destroy his reason and drive him to his own destruction.
words.name: Sanjaya

words.def: Sanjīvanī (संजीवनी):Sanjeevani is a magical herb mentioned in the Ramayana when, Lakshmana is badly wounded and is nearly killed by Ravana. Hanuman was called upon to fetch this herb from the mount Dronagiri a.k.a. Mahodaya in the Himalayas. Sushena took the life-giving plant and made Lakshman to smell its savour, so that he rose up whole and well.
words.name: Sanjīvanī

words.def: Sankula Yuddha (संकुल युद्ध): A melee, confused fight, a soldiers battle as distinguished from the combats of heroes.
words.name: Sankula Yuddha

words.def: Santā (संता): Daughter of Dasharatha, Wife of sage Rishyasringa.
words.name: Santā

words.def: Sāntanu (सांतनु): King of Hastinapura, father of Bhishma.
words.name: Sāntanu

words.def: Sanyāsin (सन्यासिन): One who has renounced the world and its concerns.
words.name: Sanyāsin

words.def: Saran (सारण): The spy of Ravana, Mentioned in Ramayana Yuddha Kanda/Sarga 26, who tells Ravana about strength of the army of vanaras.
words.name: Saran

words.def: Sarasana (सरसन): One of the Kaurava brothers who died in the war.
words.name: Sarasana

words.def: Sharmishtha (सरमिष्‍ठा): Princess and daughter of asura king Vrishaparva, wife of Yayati, who got angry with Devayani and slapped and pushed her into a dry well. Sarmishtha gave birth to Druhyu, Anu, and Puru.
words.name: Sharmishtha

words.def: Saraswati (सरस्वती): Saraswati is the first of the three great goddesses of Hinduism, the other two being Lakshmi and Durga. Saraswati is the consort of Lord Brahmā, the Creator.
words.name: Saraswati

words.def: Sarayū (सरयू): Sarayu was an ancient Indian river, sometimes thought of at probably today's Ghaghara river, and sometimes as a tributary. The river where Lakshamana practices austerities.
words.name: Sarayū

words.def: Satanika (सतनिक): Virata's son whose bead was severed by Drona.
words.name: Satanika

words.def: Satī (सती): One of name of Dākshāyani, Dākshāyani is the consort of Shiva. Other names for Dākshāyani include Gaurī, Umā, Aparnā, Lalithā, Sivakāmini etc. Sati is also the term for the immolation of a widow on her husband's pyre in Hinduism.
words.name: Satī

words.def: Satyajit (सत्यजित): A Panchala prince, a hero who stood by Yudhishthira to prevent his being taken prisoner by Drona, while Arjuna was away answering a challenge by the Samsaptakas (the Trigartas).
words.name: Satyajit

words.def: Satyaki (सत्यकि): A Yadava warrior, friend of Krishna and the Pandavas who advocated collecting their forces and defeating the unrighteous Duryodhana.
words.name: Satyaki

words.def: Satya Nārāyana (सत्य नारायण): Vishnu, Embodiment as Krishna.
words.name: Satya Nārāyana

words.def: Satyavān (सत्यवान): Meaning the truth-speaker, husband of Savitri. The oldest known version of the story of Savitri and Satyavan is found in "The Book of the Forest" of the Mahabharata.
words.name: Satyavān

words.def: Satyavatī (सत्यवती): A fisherman's daughter who possessed uncommon beauty and emanated a divinely sweet fragrance and king Santanu became enamored of her, married her and made her his queen. The wife of Bhishma's father, Shantanu.
words.name: Satyavatī

words.def: Satyavrata (सत्यव्रत): Warrior on the Kaurava side.
words.name: Satyavrata

words.def: Saugandhika (सौगंधिका): A plant that produced a very beautiful and fragrant flower that Bhima went to get for Draupadi.
words.name: Saugandhika

words.def: Sāvitrī (सावित्री): Wife of Satyavan.
words.name: Sāvitrī

words.def: Savyasachi (सव्‍यसाचि): Ambidexter, one who can use both hands with equal facility and effect. A name of Arjuna who could use his bow with the same skill with either hands.
words.name: Savyasachi

words.def: Shakti (शक्‍ती): An aspect of Devi and a personification of God as the Divine Mother who represents the active, dynamic principles of feminine power.
words.name: Shakti

words.def: Shaktism(शाक्तं): Lit., "doctrine of power" or "doctrine of the Goddess" is a denomination of Hinduism that focuses worship upon Shakti or Devi – the Hindu Divine Mother – as the absolute, ultimate Godhead. It is, along with Shaivism and Vaisnavism, one of the three primary schools of Hinduism.
words.name: Shaktism

words.def: Shakuntalā (शकुन्‍तला): Shakuntala was mother of Emperor Bharata and the wife of Dushyanta. Shakuntala was born of Vishvamitra and Menaka.
words.name: Shakuntalā

words.def: Shālwa (शाल्व): The King with whom Ambā was secretly in love.
words.name: Shālwa

words.def: Shankara (शंकर): A name of Shiva; A great magician, friend of Chand Sagar.
words.name: Shankara

words.def: Śankha (शंख): Shankha is the divine Counch or sea shell, which is one of the insignia in the Hindu God Vishnu's hands. The sound emitted from Shankha when blown, is too divine, that is used for regular rituals for Vishnu. Śankha was also the name of one of sons of King Virata who was killed in Mahabharata.
words.name: Śankha

words.def: Shantanu (शान्‍तनु): Shantanu was a king of Hastinapura, father of Bhishma. Shantanu weds Satyavati, a ferryman's daughter.
words.name: Shantanu

words.def: Shatrughna (शत्रुघ्‍न): One of Dasharatha's four sons, King of Madhu.
words.name: Shatrughna

words.def: Śatapatha brāhmaṇa (शतपथ ब्राह्मण): Shatapatha Brahmana ("Brahmana of one-hundred paths"), abbreviated ŚB) is one of the prose texts describing the Vedic ritual, associated with the White Yajurveda.
words.name: Śatapatha brāhmaṇa

words.def: Shaivism (शैव धर्म): Shaivism names the oldest of the four sects of Hinduism. Followers of Shaivism, called "Shaivas", and also "Saivas" or "Saivites", revere Shiva as the Supreme Being.
words.name: Shaivism

words.def: Śeṣa (शेष): Shesha is a naga that takes human birth through Devaki, one of the primal beings of creation. Equivalent-Ananta or Atī-sheshan. In the Puranas, Shesha is said to hold all the planets of the universe on his hoods and to constantly sing the glories of Vishnu from all his mouths.
words.name: Śeṣa

words.def: Shiva (शिव): A form of Ishvara or God in Shaivism. Śiva is commonly known as "the destroyer" and is the third god of the Trimurti.
words.name: Shiva

words.def: Shikhandi (शिखण्डी): Daughter-son of Drupada, A girl turned man, warrior on the Pandava side. He had been born in an earlier lifetime as a woman named Amba, who was rejected by Bhishma for marriage.
words.name: Shikhandi

words.def: Shishupāla (शिषुपाल): Shishupala was son of Damaghosha, king of Chedi, by Srutadeva, sister of Vasudeva; he was therefore cousin of Krishna, but he was Krishna's implacable foe, because Krishna had carried off Rukmini, his intended wife. Shishupāla was Identical with Hiranyakashipu who was slain by Krishnaat the time of Dharmaputra's Rajasuya sacrifice.
words.name: Shishupāla

words.def: Shivi (शिवि): Shivi was a great, powerful and generous king. Indra and Agni once tested his generosity by becoming birds when the king gave flesh from his body to fulfil his duty.
words.name: Shivi

words.def: Shri (श्री): Another name of Lakshmi, a goddess, the delight of Vishnu.
words.name: Shri

words.def: Shri Krishna (श्री कृष्‍ण): See Krishna.
words.name: Shri Krishna

words.def: Shrutkīrti (श्रुत्‍कीर्ति): Daughter of Kushadhwaja; bestowed on Shatrughna.
words.name: Shrutkīrti

words.def: Shudra (शुद्र): One of the four castes in Hindu tradition, consisting of artisans, cleaners and labourers.
words.name: Shudra

words.def: Shukracharya (शुक्राचार्य): Shukracharya was a guru in Hindu mythology. Known as the guru of the Asuras, he is also associated with the planet Shukra (Venus) which is named after him. He was born as the son of Rishi Brighu and his wife Ushana.
words.name: Shukracharya

words.def: Siddhāshrama (सिद्धाश्रम): The Shiva's hermitage, Where Rama and Vishvamitra sacrifice for many days.
words.name: Siddhāshrama

words.def: Simhanada (सिंहनाद): A lion-note or roar; a deep roar of defiance or triumph which warriors were wont to utter to inspire confidence in their friends, of terror in their enemies.
words.name: Simhanada

words.def: Sindhu (सिन्धु): The Indus River, Urdu دریائے سندھ; Tibetan: Sengge Chu ('Lion River'); Persian: Hindu; Greek: Sinthos; Pashto: Abaseen ("The Father of Rivers"); Mehran (an older name)) is the longest and most important river in Pakistan. Originating in the Tibetan plateau in the vicinity of Lake Mansarovar.
words.name: Sindhu

words.def: Sinhikha (सिंहिख): The grim rakshasa who rose from the sea and caught Hanumana, when he coursed through the air like Garuda in search of Sita.
words.name: Sinhikha

words.def: Sini (सिनि): One of the suitors to Devaki's hand. A kinsman of the Kauravas.
words.name: Sini

words.def: Sītā (सीता): Sita was the wife of Rama, and is esteemed an exemplar of womanly and wifely virtue. Sita was herself an avatāra of Lakshmi, Vishnu's eternal consort, who chose to reincarnate herself on Earth as Sita, and endure an arduous life, in order to provide humankind an example of such virtues.
words.name: Sītā

words.def: Sloka (श्‍लोक): A verse of lines in Sanskrit, typically recited as a prayer.
words.name: Sloka

words.def: Smarta (स्‍मर्त): A Hindu denomination, which follows Advaita philosophy and considers that all gods are manifestations of Ishvar.
words.name: Smarta

words.def: Śruti (श्रुति): A canon of Hindu scriptures. Shruti is believed to have no author; rather a divine recording of the "cosmic sounds of truth", heard by rishis.
words.name: Śruti

words.def: Soma (सोम): A ritual drink of importance among Hindus. It is frequently mentioned in the Rigveda, which contains many hymns praising its energizing or intoxicating qualities.
words.name: Soma

words.def: Somadutta (सोमदत्त): One of the suitors to Devaki's hand. A kinsman of the Kauravas.
words.name: Somadutta

words.def: Sthūṇa (स्थूण): A Yaksha, follower of Kubera, who exchanges his identity with Shikhandin, A rakshasa who helps disturb Vishvamitra's sacrifices.
words.name: Sthūṇa

words.def: Subahu (सुबाहु): King of Kulinda in the Himalayas, ally of the Kauravas, Subahu was a demon who tried to interrupt Viswamitra's yaga. He was slain by Lord Rama. King of Chedi.
words.name: Subahu

words.def: Subhadra (सुभद्रा): Wife of Arjuna, sister of Sri Krishna and mother of Abhimanyu.
words.name: Subhadra

words.def: Subrahmaniam (सुब्रहमण्यम): The southern mountain deity.
words.name: Subrahmaniam

words.def: Sudakshina (सुदक्षिण): A warrior on the Kaurava side.
words.name: Sudakshina

words.def: Sudarsana (सुदर्सण): A warrior on the Kaurava army.
words.name: Sudarsana

words.def: Sudarshana Chakra (सुदर्शन चक्र): Sudarshan Chakra is a spinning disc like weapon with very sharp edge, which is one of the weapons in the Hindu God Vishnu's hands.
words.name: Sudarshana Chakra

words.def: Sudeshna (सुदेषणा): Queen of King Virata whom Sairandhri (Draupadi) served.
words.name: Sudeshna

words.def: Sudeva (सुदेव): A Brahman who traced Damayanti in Chedi and later helps Damayanti in her quest to find Nala. He was friend of Damayanti's brother.
words.name: Sudeva

words.def: Sugrīva (सुग्रीव): Monkey-king, friend of Sri Rama, and brother of mighty Vali whom Sri Rama killed.
words.name: Sugrīva

words.def: Sujata (सुजाता): Daughter of Sage Uddalaka and wife of Kagola, his disciple who had virtue and devotion but not much of erudition, mother of Ashtavakra.
words.name: Sujata

words.def: Śuka (सुक): A sage, son of Vyasa, who related the Bhagavata Purana to King Parikshit, grandson of Arjuna.
words.name: Śuka

words.def: Sukanyā (सुकन्‍या): Meaning - Fair-maid, The wife of Chyavana whom the Ashvins beheld at her bath, bare of any garment.
words.name: Sukanyā

words.def: Sumān (सुमन): Son of Asamanja.
words.name: Sumān

words.def: Sumatī (सुमती): Wife of Sagara.
words.name: Sumatī

words.def: Sumitra (सुमित्र): Abhimanyu's charioteer.
words.name: Sumitra

words.def: Sumitrā (सुमित्रा): One of Dasharatha's three wives; mother of Lakshamana and Shatrughna.
words.name: Sumitrā

words.def: Sunda (सुन्‍द): Sunda and Upasunda were two brave and poerful asura princes who performed austerities to please Brahma, who bestowed them the boon that nobody else would slay them, other than each other. Later Brahma created a beautiful apsara Tilottama to creat differences within and destroyed them mutually.
words.name: Sunda

words.def: Sunitī (सुनिती): Mother of Dhruva.
words.name: Sunitī

words.def: Supārshwa (सुपार्शव): One of Ravana's counsellors.
words.name: Supārshwa

words.def: Surabhi (सुरभि): The wish-bestowing cow that came first from the sea in the process of churning of the Ocean by gods and daityas.
words.name: Surabhi

words.def: Surpankhā (सुर्पण्खा): A rākshasī; sister of ravana; desires Rama; seeks to become Lakshamana's wife who attempts to slay Sita.
words.name: Surpankhā

words.def: Supratika (सुप्रतिक): Name of King Bhagadatta's elephant.
words.name: Supratika

words.def: Sūrya (सूर्य): A solar deity who is one of the three main Vedic Gods.
words.name: Sūrya

words.def: Susarma (सुसर्म): King of Trigarta, a supporter of the Kauravas who backed the proposal to invade Matsya, Virata's country.
words.name: Susarma

words.def: Sushena (सुषेन): A monkey chief ; at siege of Lanka.
words.name: Sushena

words.def: Sushruta Samhita (सुश्रुतसंहिता): Suśruta Saṃhitā is a Sanskrit redaction text on all of the major concepts of ayurvedic medicine with innovative chapters on surgery, attributed to Sushruta, likely a historical sage physician of 6th century BCE.
words.name: Sushruta Samhita

words.def: Sūtra (सूत्र): Sūtra refers to an aphorism or a collection of such aphorisms in the form of a book or text. 'Sutras' form a school of Vedic study, related to and somewhat later than the Upanishads.
words.name: Sūtra

words.def: Suvarna (सुवर्ण): A soldier on the Kaurava side.
words.name: Suvarna

words.def: Sri Rama (श्रीराम): Also knew as Rama, Ramachandra or Sri Rama. Hanumana tells Bhima how he was deeply thrilled when he happened to touch Rama's body. This king of Ayodhya was banished to the forest for fourteen years, killed Ravana the king of Lanka who abducted his wife, Sita.
words.name: Sri Rama

words.def: Srinjayas (श्रीन्‍जय): Pandava supporters.
words.name: Srinjayas

words.def: Srutayu (श्रुतायु), Astutayu (अस्‍तुतायु): Two brothers fighting on the Kaurava side attacked Arjuna but were killed.
words.name: Srutayu

words.def: Srutayudha (श्रुतायुद्घ): A Kaurava warrior whose mace hurled at Krishna rebounded fiercely, killing Srutayudha himself. Her mother Parnasa had obtained that gift from Varuna who had specified that the mace should not be used against one who does not fight, else it would kill the person who hurls it.
words.name: Srutayudha

words.def: Swarga (स्‍वर्ग): An Olympian paradise, a place where all wishes and desires are gratfied, The heaven of Indra where mortals after death enjoy the results of their good deeds on earth.
words.name: Swarga

words.def: Sveta (स्‍वेत): A son of King Virata who fell in battle to Bhishma's arrow.
words.name: Sveta

words.def: Swayamvara (स्‍वयं‍वर): Meaning - Own-choice, Swayamvara, in ancient India, was a practice of choosing a life partner, among a list of suitors by a girl of marriageable age.
words.name: Swayamvara

words.def: Syala (स्याल): A Yadava prince who insulted the sage Gargya, and was the cause of his becoming the father of Kalayavana, a great foe of Krishna and the Yadava family.
words.name: Syala

words.def: Tall (टल्‍ल): One of Ravana's counsellors
words.name: Tall

words.def: Tārā (तारा): See Tara (Devi)
words.name: Tārā

words.def: Tāragam (तारगम): Tāragam is the name of forest, where dwelt ten thousand heretical rishis, who taught that the universe is eternal, that souls have no lord and that performance of works alone suffices for the attainment of salvation. Shiva taught them lesson and they became his followers. This legend is associated with Shiva's dance.
words.name: Tāragam

words.def: Tāraka (तारक): A demon slain by Kumara, the first son of Shiva.
words.name: Tāraka

words.def: Tandava (ताण्‍डव): Siva's cosmic dance.
words.name: Tandava

words.def: Tantra (तंत्र): The esoteric Hindu traditions of rituals and yoga. Tantra can be summarised as a family of voluntary rituals modeled on those of the Vedas, together with their attendant texts and lineages.
words.name: Tantra

words.def: Tantripala: Assumed name of Sahadeva at Virata's court.
words.name: Tantripala

words.def: Tarpana or Tarpan (तर्पण ): Sacrament, a death rite, also performed during the Pitru Paksha.
words.name: Tarpana

words.def: Tilottamā (तिलोत्तमा): Tilottama was an Apsaras. She is reputed to have been created by Vishwakarma from Tila seeds. She was responsible for bringing out the mutual destruction of the Asuras Sunda and Upasunda.
words.name: Tilottamā

words.def: Tripura (त्रिपुरा): Tripura (meaning three cities, in Sanskrit) was constructed by the great architect Mayasura. They were great cities of prosperity, power and dominance over the world, but due to their impious nature, Maya's cities were destroyed by Lord Shiva.
words.name: Tripura

words.def: Trishira (त्रिसिर): Trishira that is, one having three heads, was an asura mentioned in the Ramayana. He was one of the seven sons of Ravana, and his other brothers were Indrajit, Prahasta, Atikaya, Akshayakumara, Devantaka and Narantaka.
words.name: Trishira

words.def: Tulsī Dās (तुलसीदास): Goswami Tulsidas (1532–1623) was a Hindu poet and philosopher, translator of the epics into vernacular. Tulsidas wrote twelve books and is considered the greatest and most famous of Hindi poets.
words.name: Tulsī Dās

words.def: Uchchaihshravas: Uchchaihsravas was the white horse of Indra, produced at the churning of the ocean. It is fed on ambrosia, and is held to be the king of horses.
words.name: Uchchaihshravas

words.def: Udayana: Udayana was a prince of the Lunar race, and son of Sahasranika, who is the hero of a popular story. He was king of Vatsa, and is commonly called Vatsaraja. His capital was Kausambi. Also a name of Agastya.
words.name: Udayana

words.def: Uddalaka: A great sage and the teacher of Vedanta.
words.name: Uddalaka

words.def: Uddhava: The friend and counselor of Krishna. According to some he was Krishna 's cousin, being son of Devabhaga, the brother of Vasudeva. He was also called Pavanayadhi.
words.name: Uddhava

words.def: Ugrasena (उग्रसेन): one-time King of Yadavas; deposed by his son Kams. His wife was Pavanrekha. Krishna killed Kams and established Ugrasena on throne.
words.name: Ugrasena

words.def: Ujjayini (उज्‍जयिनि) or Ujjain (उज्जैन): is an ancient city of central India, in the Malwa region of Madhya Pradesh near which the ancient throne of Vikramaditya was discovered, one of the seven sacred cities of the Hindus, where the Kumbh Mela is held every twelve years. It is also home to Mahakaleshwar Jyotirlinga, one of the twelve Jyotirlinga shrines to the god Shiva.
words.name: UjjayiniUjjain

words.def: Ulūka (उलूक): 'An owl.' Son of Kitava. He was king of a country and people of the same name. He was an ally of the Kauravas, and acted as their envoy to the Pandavas.
words.name: Ulūka

words.def: Ulūpī (उलूपी): A daughter of Kauravya, Raja of the Nagas, with whom Arjuna contracted a kind of marriage. She was nurse to her stepson, Babhruvahana, and had great influence over him. According to the Vishnu Purana she had a son named Iravat.
words.name: Ulūpī

words.def: Umadevī (उमादेवी): Wife of Shiva.
words.name: Umadevī

words.def: Unchhavritti (उन्‍छवृत्ती): The life of a mendicant, begging his food.
words.name: Unchhavritti

words.def: Upachitra (उपचित्र): One of King Dhritarashtra's sons who perished in the war.
words.name: Upachitra

words.def: Upanishad (उपनिषद्): Part of the Hindu Śruti scriptures which primarily discuss meditation and philosophy, seen as religious instructions by most schools of Hinduism.
words.name: Upanishad

words.def: Upaplavya (उपप्‍लव्‍य): A place in Matsya Kingdom, where the Pandavas settled after their exile of thirteen years.
words.name: Upaplavya

words.def: Uparichara: A Vasu or demigod, who, according to the Mahabharata, became king of Chedi by command of Indra. He had five sons by his wife; and by an Apsaras, named Adrika, condemned to live on earth in the form of a fish, he had a son named Matsya (fish), and a daughter, Satyavati, who was the mother of Vyasa.
words.name: Uparichara

words.def: Upasunda (उपसुन्‍द): Sund and Upasunda were two brave and poerful asura princes who performed austerities to please Brahma,who besowed them the boon that nobody else would slay them, other than each other. Later Brahma created a beautiful apsara Tilottama to creat differences within and destroyed them.
words.name: Upasunda

words.def: Urmilā (उर्मिला): Second daughter of Janaka; bestowed on Lakshmana.
words.name: Urmilā

words.def: Urvasī (उर्वसी): An apsara in Indra's court, whose amorous overtures Arjuna declined.
words.name: Urvasī

words.def: Ushā (उषा): Wife of Aniruddha, daughter of Banasur.
words.name: Ushā

words.def: Ushanas (उशना): Ushanas were appointed as priests of asuras, who knew the science of bringing to life.
words.name: Ushanas

words.def: Uttanka (उत्‍तंक): Uttanka was a pupil of Veda, the third pupil of Dhaumya rishi. The other two pupils of Uttanka were Janamejaya and Poshya.
words.name: Uttanka

words.def: Uttara (उत्तर): A son of the Raja of Virata. Uttara was killed in battle by Salya.
words.name: Uttara

words.def: Uttarā (उत्तरा): A daughter of the Raja of Virata. She married Abhimanyu, son of Arjuna.
words.name: Uttarā

words.def: Uttar kānda (उत्तरकांड): The part of epic Ramayana added later to the work of Valmiki.
words.name: Uttar kānda

words.def: Varaha (वराह): The third Avatar of the Hindu Godhead Vishnu, in the form of a Boar. He appeared in order to defeat Hiranyaksha, a demon who had taken the Earth (Prithvi) and carried it to the bottom of what is described as the cosmic ocean in the story.
words.name: Varaha

words.def: Vaiśampāyana (वैशंपायन): A celebrated sage who was the original teacher of the Black Yajur-Veda. He was a pupil of the great Vyasa, from whom he learned the Mahabharata, which he afterwards recited to King Janamejaya at a festival.
words.name: Vaiśampāyana

words.def: Vaishnava (वैष्‍णव): A sacrifice performed by Duryodhana in the forest. Yayati, Mandhata, Bharata and others also performed it.
words.name: Vaishnava

words.def: Vaishnava mantra (वैष्‍णव मंत्र): An invocation which endows a missile with some of the irresistible power of Vishnu.
words.name: Vaishnava mantra

words.def: Vaishnavism (वैष्णव धर्म): Vaishnavism is a tradition of Hinduism, distinguished from other schools by its worship of Vishnu or his associated avatars, principally as Rama and Krishna, as the original and supreme God.
words.name: Vaishnavism

words.def: Vaishrāvan (वैश्रावण): Elder brother of Ravana to whom Rama returned Pushpaka after the death of Ravana.
words.name: Vaishrāvan

words.def: Vaishya (वैश्य): One of the four fundamental varnas (colours) in Hindu tradition comprising merchants, artisans, and landowners.
words.name: Vaishya

words.def: Vaivasvata Manu (वैवस्वत मनु): Vaivasvata Manu (also Manu Vaivasvate) is one of the 14 Manus. He is considered the progenitor of the current Manvantara, which is the 7th of the 14 that make up the current Kalpa, each Kalpa making up a day of Brahma. He was born to Saranya and Vivasvat and was the King of Dravida during the epoch of the Matsya Purana.He was the founder of the Suryavansha race of kings.
words.name: Vaivasvata Manu

words.def: Vajrahanu (वज्रहनु): One of Ravana's generals.
words.name: Vajrahanu

words.def: Vajrayudha (वज्रयुद्ध): The weapon with which Indra killed Visvarupa on suspicion because his mother belonged to the asura tribe of daityas.
words.name: Vajrayudha

words.def: Valala (वलाल): Assumed name of Bhima when, he worked as a cook at Virata's court.
words.name: Valala

words.def: Vālī (वाली): One of five great monkeys in Ramayana, a son of Indra, Monkey-king of Kishkindha and the cruel elder brother of Sugriva. He was killed by Rama.
words.name: Vālī

words.def: Vālmikī (वाल्मिकी): Maharishi Valmiki is the author of the Hindu epic Ramayana, a brahman by birth, connected with the kings of Ayodhya, contemporary of Rama who invented the shloka metre, who taught the Ramayana to Kusa and Lava.
words.name: Vālmikī

words.def: Vāmadeva (वामदेव): Vamadeva is the name of the "preserver" aspect of the god Shiva, one of five aspects of the universe he embodies. Also one of Dasharatha's priest.
words.name: Vāmadeva

words.def: Vamana (वामन): The fifth Avatara of Vishnu. He is the first Avatar of Vishnu which had a completely human form, although it was that of a dwarf brahmin.
words.name: Vamana

words.def: Vanāsur (बाणासुर): Same as Banasur, was a thousand-armed asura, powerful and terrible. He was son of Bali. Bana was a follower of Siva. Banasura had a beautiful daughter named Usha.
words.name: Vanāsur

words.def: Vanaprastha (वानप्रस्‍थ): The third stage of the dvija's life, when he is required to relinquish worldly responsibilities to his heirs and retires to the woods with his wife for an anchorite's life. A person who is living in the forest as a hermit after giving up material desires.
words.name: Vanaprastha

words.def: Vandi: Court poet of Mithila who on being defeated by Sage Ashtavakra in debate drowned himself in the ocean and went to the abode of Varuna.
words.name: Vandi

words.def: Vardhamana (वर्धमान): The northern gate of the Kuru capital Hastinapura.
words.name: Vardhamana

words.def: Varṇa (वर्ण): Means - colour, Varna refers to the four naturally existing classes of society as given in the Hindu scriptures: Brahmin, Kshatriya, Vaishya and Shudra.
words.name: Varṇa

words.def: Vārṇāvata (वारणावत): One of the provinces asked by Pandavas. A forest in which the Pandavas were asked to stay in a wax-house which was to be set on fire at midnight in order to kill the Pandavas while they were asleep.
words.name: Vārṇāvata

words.def: Varṣṇeya: The charioteer of Rituparna, king of Ayodhya, who accompanied with Bahuka.
words.name: Varṣṇeya

words.def: Varuṇa (वरुण): A god of the sky, of rain and of the celestial ocean, as well as a god of law and of the underworld.
words.name: Varuṇa

words.def: Varuṇī (वरुणी): The goddess of wine.
words.name: Varuṇī

words.def: Vāsava (वासव): Name of arrow of death, given by Indra to Karna.
words.name: Vāsava

words.def: Vashiṣtha (वशिष्‍ठ): Vasishtha was chief of the seven venerated sages (or Saptarishi) and the Rajaguru of the Suryavamsha. He was the manasaputra of Brahma. He had in his possession the divine cow Kamadhenu, and Nandini her child, who could grant anything to their owners. Arundhati was his wife.
words.name: Vashiṣtha

words.def: Vasudhana (वसुधन): Another warrior who perished in the battle on the Twelfth Day.
words.name: Vasudhana

words.def: Vasudeva (वसुदेव): Descendant of Yadu, husband of Rohini and Devaki. An epithet of Krishna. It means both son of Vasudeva and the supreme spirit that pervades the universe.
words.name: Vasudeva

words.def: Vasuki: King of the Nagas or serpents who live in Patala. He was used by the gods and Asuras for a coil round the mountain Mandara at the churning of the ocean.
words.name: Vasuki

words.def: Vatapi: Vatapi and Ilvala, two Rakshasas, sons either of Hrada or Viprachitti. They are mentioned in the Ramayana as dwelling in the Dandaka forest.
words.name: Vatapi

words.def: Vayu (वायु): The god of air and wind who is also father of Bhima and Hanuman.
words.name: Vayu

words.def: Veda (वेद): Collectively refers to a corpus of ancient Indo-Aryan religious literature that are considered by adherents of Hinduism to be revealed knowledge. Many Hindus believe the Vedas existed since the beginning of creation.
words.name: Veda

words.def: Veda Vyasa (वेद व्‍यास): Vyasa, author of the Mahabharata.
words.name: Veda Vyasa

words.def: Vibhandaka: An ascetic who retired from the world and lived in the forest with his infant son Rishyasringa.
words.name: Vibhandaka

words.def: Vibhīshaṇa (विभीषण): Vibhishana was a rakshasa, brother of Ravana. He was of a noble character and advised Ravana, who kidnapped and abducted Sita, to return her to Rama.
words.name: Vibhīshaṇa

words.def: Vichitravīrya (विचित्रवीर्य): Vichitravirya was Bhishma's half brother, the younger son of queen Satyavati and king Santanu. Chitrangada, the elder brother of Vichitravirya, succeeded Santanu to the throne of Hastinapura. When he died childless, Vichitravirya, became king. He had two sons, Dhritarashtra and Pandu.
words.name: Vichitravīrya

words.def: Vidarbha: Birar, and probably including with it the adjoining district of Beder, which name is apparently a corruption of Vidarbha. The capital was Kundinapura, the modern "Kundapur", about forty miles east of Amravati.
words.name: Vidarbha

words.def: Vidura (विदुर): Vidura was a son of a maid-servant who served the Queens of Hastinapura, Queen Ambika and Ambalika. A friend of pandavas. After Krishna, he was the most trusted advisor to the Pandavas and had warned them repeatedly about Duryodhana's plots.
words.name: Vidura

words.def: Vijaya (विजय): Name of Karna's bow.
words.name: Vijaya

words.def: Vijayadashami (विजयादशमी):A festival celebrated on the tenth day of the bright fortnight (Shukla Paksha) of the Hindu autumn month of Ashvin.
words.name: Vijayadashami

words.def: Vikarna (विकर्ण): A son of Dhritarashtra who declared the staking of Draupadi illegal, as Yudhishthira himself was a slave and had lost all his rights. Therefore, the Kauravas had not won Draupadi legally, he held
words.name: Vikarna

words.def: Vikramaditya (विक्रमादित्य): Vikramāditya is the name of a legendary king of Ujjain, famed for his wisdom, valour and magnanimity. The title "Vikramaditya" has also been assumed by many kings in Indian history, notably the Gupta King Chandragupta II.
words.name: Vikramaditya

words.def: Vikukshi: A king of the Solar race, who succeeded his father, Ikshwaku. He received the name of Sasada, 'hare-eater.' He was sent by his father to hunt and obtain flesh suitable for offerings. Being weary and hungry he ate a hare, and Vasishtha, the priest, declared that this act had defiled all the food, for what remained was but his leavings.
words.name: Vikukshi

words.def: Vinda (विन्‍द), Anuvinda (अनुविन्‍द): Two brothers kings of Avanti, great soldiers whom were on the Kaurava side, they suffered defeat at the hands of Yudhamanyu.
words.name: Vinda

words.def: Vindhyas (विन्‍ध्य): Vindhyas is a range of hills in central India, which geographically separates the Indian subcontinent into northern India (the Indo-Gangetic plain) and Southern India.
words.name: Vindhyas

words.def: Virāta (विराट): King of Matsya, the country which was suggested by Bhima to live in incognito during the thirteenth year of their exile.
words.name: Virāta

words.def: Vīrabhadra (वीरभद्र): Vīrabhadra was a demon that sprang from Shiva's lock of hair. Shiva burnt with anger when not invited in a sacrifice by Daksha and his wife Sati released the inward consuming fire and fell dead at Daksha's feet. Shiva burned with anger, and tore from his head a lock of hair, glowing with energy, and cast upon the earth. The terrible demon Vīrabhadra sprang from it. On the direction of Shiva, Virabhadra appeared with Shiva's ganas in the midst of Daksha's assembly like a storm wind and broke the sacrificial vessels, polluted the offerings, insulted the priests and finally cut off Daksha's head.
words.name: Vīrabhadra

words.def: Virādha (विराध): A fierce rakshasa who seizes Sita.
words.name: Virādha

words.def: Vīrasen: Father of Raja Nala, king of Nishadha.
words.name: Vīrasen

words.def: Virochana (विरोचन): An asura, son of Prahlada, and father of Bali. He is also called Drisana. When the earth was milked, Virochana acted as the calf of the Asuras.
words.name: Virochana

words.def: Vishnu (विष्‍णु): A form of God, to whom many Hindus pray. For Vaishnavas, He is the only Ultimate Reality or God. In Trimurti belief, He is the second aspect of God in the Trimurti (also called the Hindu Trinity), along with Brahma and Shiva. Known as the Preserver, He is most famously identified with His Avatars, especially Krishna and Rama.
words.name: Vishnu

words.def: Vishvakarmā (विश्वकर्मा): Vishwakarma is the presiding deity of all craftsmen and architects. he is the divine craftsman of the whole universe, and the official builder of all the gods' palaces. Vishwakarma is also the designer of all the flying chariots of the gods, and all their weapons.
words.name: Vishvakarmā

words.def: Viśvamitra (विश्‍वामित्र): Brahmarishi Visvamitra or Vishvamitra was one of the most venerated rishi or sages of since ancient times in India. He was originally a Kshatriya but by austerities earned the title of Brahmarishi. He is also credited as the author of most of Mandala 3 of the Rigveda, including the Gayatri Mantra.
words.name: Viśvamitra

words.def: Visoka (विसोक): Bhima's charioteer.
words.name: Visoka

words.def: Visvarupa (विस्‍वरुप): Name of Twashta's son who became the preceptor of the gods, Brihaspati having left when insulted by Indra.
words.name: Visvarupa

words.def: Vivimsati (विविस्‍मति): A Kaurava hero and Duryodhana's brother.
words.name: Vivimsati

words.def: Viswarupa (विस्‍वरुप): All-pervading, all-including form. See the description in the Bhagavad Gita chapter eleven.
words.name: Viswarupa

words.def: Vriddhakshatra (वृद्घक्षत्र): King of the Sindhus, father of Jayadratha into whose lap his son Jayadratha's head was caused to fall by Arjuna after cutting off Jayadratha's head.
words.name: Vriddhakshatra

words.def: Vrika (वृक): A Panchala prince who fell in battle.
words.name: Vrika

words.def: Vrikasthala (वृकस्थल): One of the provinces asked by Pandavas. This province and town were situated in the southern part of Kuru Kingdom (Kuru Proper + Kurujangala). Krishna visited the town of Vrikasthala (in Gurgaon district of Hariyana) and camped there for onee night (5,84).
words.name: Vrikasthala

words.def: Vrindavana: A wood in the district of Mathura where Krishna passed his youth, under the name of Gopala, among the cowherds.
words.name: Vrindavana

words.def: Vrisha (वृष), Achala(अचल): Sakuni's brothers.
words.name: Vrisha

words.def: Vrishdarbha (वृषदर्भ): A king of Benares, associated with the story of "The king, the Pigeon, and Hawk".
words.name: Vrishdarbha

words.def: Vrishni (वृषणि): A descendent of Yadu, and the ancestor from whom Krsna got the name Varshneya
words.name: Vrishni

words.def: Vrishnis, (वृषणि): The descendant of Vrishni, son of Madhu, whose ancestor was the eldest son of Yadu. Krsna belonged to this branch of the Lunar race. The people of Dwaraka were known as the Vrishnis. Tribals of this race were devoted to the Pandavas, who with Sri Krishna visited the Pandavas in their exile.
words.name: Vrishnis

words.def: Vrishasena (वृषसेन): Son of Karna, A warrior on the Kaurava side, slain by Arjuna.
words.name: Vrishasena

words.def: Vritra (वृत्र): Means "the enveloper". Vritra, was an Asura and also a serpent or dragon, the personification of drought and enemy of Indra. Vritra was also known in the Vedas as Ahi ("snake"), cognate with Azhi Dahaka of Zoroastrian mythology and he is said to have had three heads. He was son of Twashta who was defeated by Indra's weapons Vajrayudha. He was born out of his father's sacrificial flames and became Indra's mortal enemy.
words.name: Vritra

words.def: Vrikodara (वृकोदर): Wolf-bellied, an epithet of Bhima, denoting his slimness of waist and insatiable hunger.
words.name: Vrikodara

words.def: Vyasa (व्‍यास): Compiler of the Vedas, son of sage Parasara.
words.name: Vyasa

words.def: Vyuha (व्‍युह): Battle arrays.
words.name: Vyuha

words.def: Yādavas (यादव): The descendants of Yadu, who dwelt by the Yamuna river.
words.name: Yādavas

words.def: Yadu (यदु): A prince of the lunar dynasty; Yadu is the name of one of the five Aryan clans mentioned in the Rig Veda. His descendants are called Yadavas. The epic Mahabharata and Puranas refer to Yadu as the eldest son of mythological king Yayati.
words.name: Yadu

words.def: Yaduvamsis: Those of the clan of Yadu.
words.name: Yaduvamsis

words.def: Yajnignna (यज्ञ): A Vedic ritual of sacrifice performed to please the Devas, or sometimes to the Supreme Spirit Brahman. Often it involves a fire, which represents the god Agni, in the centre of the stage and items are offered into the fire.
words.name: Yajnignna

words.def: Yakṣa (यक्ष): Yaksha or Yakkha (Pāli) is the name of a broad class of nature-spirits or minor deities who appear in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. The feminine form of the word is yakṣī or yakṣiṇī (Pāli: yakkhī or yakkhinī). subjects of Kubera, the god of wealth.
words.name: Yakṣa

words.def: Yama (यम): Yama, also known as Yamarāja (यमराज) is the lord of death, first recorded in the Vedas. God of dharma, whose son was Yudhishthira. It is he whose questions Yudhishthira answered correctly whereupon his dead brothers were brought back to life on the banks of the enchanted pool.
words.name: Yama

words.def: Yamas: A yama (Sanskrit), literally translates as a "restraint", a rule or code of conduct for living virtuously.
words.name: Yamas

words.def: Yamuna (जमुना): A river (also spelled Jamuna), joining with the Ganges. Literally meaning "twins" in Sanskrit, as it runs parallel to the Ganges, its name is mentioned at many places in the Rig Veda, written during the Vedic period ca between 1700–1100 BCE, and also in the later Atharvaveda, and the Brahmanas including Aitareya Brahmana and Shatapatha Brahmana.
words.name: Yamuna

words.def: Yashodā (यशोदा): Yasodā was wife of Nanda and foster-mother of, Krishna, who was given to them by Vasudeva. Yasoda also played an important role in the upbrinding of Balarama and his sister Subhadra. She is also sometimes described as having her own daughter, known as Ekānaṅgā.
words.name: Yashodā

words.def: Yavakrida: Son of Sage Bharadwaja who was bent upon mastering the Vedas.
words.name: Yavakrida

words.def: Yayati (ययाति): Emperor of the Bharata race who rescued Devayani from the well into which she had been thrown by Sharmishtha. He later married both Devayani and Sarmishtha. One of the ancestors of the Pandavas who became prematurely old due to Sukracharya's curse.
words.name: Yayati

words.def: Yoga (योग): Spiritual practices performed primarily as a means to enlightenment (or bodhi). Traditionally, Karma Yoga, Bhakti Yoga, Jnana Yoga, and Raja Yoga are considered the four main yogas. In the West, yoga has become associated with the asanas (postures) of Hatha Yoga, popular as fitness exercises.
words.name: Yoga

words.def: Yoga Sutra (योग सूत्र): One of the six darshanas of Hindu or Vedic schools and, alongside the Bhagavad Gita and Hatha Yoga Pradipika, are a milestone in the history of Yoga.
words.name: Yoga Sutra

words.def: Yogi (योगी): One who practices yoga, These designations are mostly reserved for advanced practitioners. The word "yoga" itself—from the Sanskrit root yuj ("to yoke") --is generally translated as "union" or "integration" and may be understood as union with the Divine, or integration of body, mind, and spirit.
words.name: Yogi

words.def: Yudhāmanyu (युधामन्यु): A Panchala prince supporting the Pandavas, who was assigned the task of protecting the wheels of Arjuna's chariot along with Uttamauja. He was slain in his sleep by Ashvatthama.
words.name: Yudhāmanyu

words.def: Yudhishthira (युधिष्ठिर): Yudhishthira was the eldest son of King Pandu and Queen Kunti, king of Hastinapura and Indraprastha, and World Emperor. He was the principal protagonist of the Kurukshetra War, and for his unblemished piety, known as Dharmaraja.
words.name: Yudhishthira

words.def: Yuga (युग): In Hindu philosophy (and in the teachings of Surat Shabd Yoga) the cycle of creation is divided into four yugas (ages or eras).
words.name: Yuga

words.def: Yuga Dharma (युगधर्म): One aspect of Dharma, as understood by Hindus. Yuga dharma is an aspect of dharma that is valid for a Yuga,. The other aspect of dharma is Sanatan Dharma, dharma which is valid for eternity.
words.name: Yuga Dharma

words.def: Yuyudhāna (युयुधान): Another name of Satyaki, who was not killed in the warfare but in a mutual fight among Yadavas.
words.name: Yuyudhāna

words.def: Yuyutsu (युयुत्सू): A noble son of Dhritarashtra who bent his head in shame and sorrow when Yudhishthira lost Draupadi. He also disapproved of the unfair way in which Abhimanyu was killed.
words.name: Yuyutsu
